column2: + *Male Preponderance* in implant removal surgeries
+ *Timing of Implant Removal* not well established; AO guidelines for uncomplicated fracture healing
+ *Risks and Complications* of implant removal surgeries, including fracture, neurovascular injury, and infection
+ *Need for Concrete Indication Guidelines* for implant removal in asymptomatic patients
+ *Routine Removal* not recommended; if necessary, removal should not require a larger procedure than the index operation
+ *Patient Consent* and understanding of risks and possible complications before implant removal surgery
+ *Study Limitations:* Small sample size and short follow-up period
+ *Future Studies* needed to produce concrete literature on the patterns of removal surgeries in symptomatic implants
• Aim: To determine if L-2-aminoadipic acid (L-2-AAA) inhibits Müller cell gliosis and protects against retinal abnormalities in a rat model of acute ocular hypertension (AOH) mimicking glaucoma.
• Methodology:

column3: - Used adult male Sprague-Dawley rats.
- Induced AOH by increasing intraocular pressure (IOP) to 110 mmHg for 60 minutes.
- Divided animals into four groups: sham operation (Ctrl), AOH, AOH + phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) control, and AOH + L-2-AAA-treated group.
- Injected L-2-AAA (250 µg) into vitreous humor after 3 hours of AOH induction.
- Performed time-course examination at 1 day, 3 days, and 5 days after AOH induction.

column2: • L-2-AAA treatment significantly reduced retinal thickness in the inner plexiform layer (IPL) and inner nuclear layer after AOH induction.
• L-2-AAA treatment attenuated apoptosis of retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) and rescued the reduced number of RGCs in the AOH model.
• L-2-AAA treatment reduced glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) immunoreactivity, indicating attenuation in Müller cell gliosis.
• L-2-AAA treatment significantly attenuated tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) levels in the retinas of the AOH model.

column1: * **Laparoscopy-Assisted Endoscopic Full-Thickness Resection with Ligation Device (LAEFTR-L) for Nonampullary Superficial Duodenal Neoplasms (SDNs)**

column2: + **Procedure and Setup**

column3: - Mobilize duodenum from retroperitoneum
- Insert forward-viewing endoscope, identify target lesion, and ligate using ligation device
- Laparoscopist temporarily sutures seromuscular layer, endoscopist resects targeted lesion, and specimen retrieved intraluminally

column2: + **Patient Outcomes**

column3: - 5 patients underwent LAEFTR-L from June to September 2015
- Mean operative time: 173 minutes, mean resected specimen diameter: 24 mm, mean tumor size: 9 mm
- Complete resection achieved in all cases, with no complications

column2: + **Advantages of LAEFTR-L**

column3: - Intraluminal specimen collection, avoiding peritoneal contact
- Does not require proficient experience in endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD)

column2: + **Limitations and Future Directions**

column3: - Tumor size and location are important factors for indication
- Additional studies needed to evaluate long-term outcomes and efficacy

column1: • Caused by defects in enzymes necessary for cortisol synthesis
• Symptoms include ambiguous genitalia in females and rapid growth in both sexes
• Managed with oral glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid administration
• Four cases managed with hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone
- Adrenal masses found in all cases
• Two cases underwent adrenalectomy due to increasing mass size and virilization
- Most mutations due to recombination with inactive pseudogene (CYP21A1P)
- Classic further subclassified as salt-losing or simple virilizing
• Symptoms include ambiguous genitalia in females, hyperpigmentation, hirsutism, and virilization
• Diagnosed through newborn screening or corticotropin stimulation test
• Treated with glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids to suppress adrenal androgens and maintain growth
• Rare but higher prevalence in untreated CAH patients
• Benign tumors common, but virilizing adrenal carcinoma can occur
• Chronic poor compliance to therapy associated with tumor development
• Maintain steroid medication to avoid adrenal tumor appearance and normalize electrolyte disorder
• Follow-up imaging may help discover adrenal tumor in long-term management

column2: + **Fruits and Vegetables Intake**

column3: - Lower intake associated with poor/fair SRH in both males and females
- Females with 2 servings/day had 2.1x higher odds of poor/fair SRH
- Males with 3-4 servings/day had 2.8x higher odds of poor/fair SRH

column2: + **Fat Intake**

column3: - High fat intake associated with poor/fair SRH in both males and females
- Females with mostly high fat foods had 1.5x higher odds of poor/fair SRH
- Males with mostly high fat foods had 3.2x higher odds of poor/fair SRH

column2: + **Physical Activity**

column3: - Low physical activity associated with poor/fair SRH in females
- Females with 13 times a month or never had 1.6x higher odds of poor/fair SRH
- No significant association found in males after adjustment for covariates

column1: * **Endoscopic Injection of Dextranomer/Hyaluronic Acid (DX/HA) for Vesicoureteral Reflux (VUR)**

column2: + * FDA-approved since 2001 for grade II-IV VUR in children over one year old
+ * American Urological Association endorses it as a management option for pediatric VUR

column1: * **Intraoperative Cystography for DX/HA Injection Success Prediction**

column2: + * High-pressure cystogram and standard positional instillation cystography (PIC) techniques were compared
+ * Intraoperative cystogram had an 80% correlation with postoperative cystogram, but did not improve overall success rate
+ *Definition and Prevalence*

column3: - Maximal atrial diameter >10 mm
- Prevalence: 0.3-1.5%
- Severity: mild (10-12 mm), moderate (12-15 mm), severe (>15 mm)

column2: + *Causes and Types*

column3: - Imbalance in CSF production/absorption (obstructive)
- Abnormal cerebral development (agenesis of corpus callosum, neuronal disorders)
- Destructive processes (vascular insults, infections)

column2: + *Additional Anomalies and Prognosis*

column3: - Incidence: up to 70-85% depending on severity
- Isolated/unilateral ventriculomegaly has lower morbidity/mortality
- MRI helps detect additional cerebral anomalies

column2: + *Technique*

column3: - Performed on 1.5T scanners, no demonstrated adverse effects
- HASTE sequence: short acquisition time, good signal-to-noise ratio
- T1-weighted imaging: detects hemorrhages/calcifications, longer scanning time

column2: + *Limitations*

column3: - Fetal motion impact on image acquisition
- Relatively low spatial resolution compared to ultrasound
- No contra-indications specific to pregnancy

column2: + *Advantages over Ultrasound*

column3: - Excellent contrast resolution (gray/white matter differentiation)
- Direct visualization of cortical region and fossa posterior
- No limiting factors like maternal obesity, amniotic fluid amount, fetal head position

column2: + *Added Value*

column3: - Detects small intraventricular blood deposits, corpus callosum dysgenesis
- Assesses fossa posterior, detects developmental anomalies
- Ideal for cortical evaluation, detects cortical malformations

column2: + *Limited Role*

column3: - Limited over ultrasound in assessing ventricle size, except in problematic cases
- Useful in second trimester for detecting small hemorrhages/callosal anomalies
- Later in pregnancy, adds information about cortical development/maturation, detects white matter pathology

column2: + *Debate and Practical Issues*

column3: - Added value in moderate/severe cases to detect",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

column2: + Lung cancer is the third most common cancer diagnosed and the leading cause of cancer-related death in the US.
+ In 2012, an estimated 226,160 patients were diagnosed with lung cancer, and 160,340 died from the disease.
+ The stage distribution of lung cancer cases diagnosed between 1999 and 2006 was: distant metastasis (56%), regional metastasis (22%), localized (15%), and unstaged (8%).
+ Five-year relative survival rates were 3.5% for distant stage, 24% for regional stage, and 52.9% for localized stage.
+ Bone is a common site of metastasis in lung cancer, with 19.8% of patients aged 65 or older having evidence of bone metastasis within a year of diagnosis.
+ SREs, such as pathological fractures, spinal cord compression, and severe pain, occurred in 51% of patients with bone metastasis.

column1: * **Impact of Bone Metastasis and SREs on Mortality**

column2: + Having a possible bone metastasis was associated with mortality among lung cancer patients, with a hazard ratio (HR) of 2.4 compared to patients without bone metastasis.
+ The association was similar for bone metastasis complicated with an SRE (HR = 2.4) and for bone metastasis without an SRE (HR = 2.4).
+ The strongest association was observed for patients with localized stage lung cancer.
+ The study was limited to patients aged 65 or older diagnosed with lung cancer between 1999 and 2005, with Medicare Part A and B coverage, and residing in SEER geographic areas.
+ Medicare data may not capture all healthcare services, and the procedures used to identify bone metastasis were not validated.
+ Other confounding factors, such as treatment factors or concurrent comorbid conditions, were not included in the analysis.
+ The data do not include information on functional status, a predictor of outcomes.
• Aim: Compare the effect of photodynamic diode laser and other smear layer removal methods on bond strength of self-adhesive cement.
• Null Hypothesis: No significant differences in push-out bond strength values after different root canal surface treatments.
• 55 extracted maxillary central incisors used.
• Teeth prepared with rotary instruments, filled with gutta percha, and post spaces created.
• Five experimental groups based on post space treatments:

column3: • Group 1: Physiological saline (NaCl).
• Group 2: Sodium hypochlorite (NaOCl).
• Group 3: Ethylene diamine tetra acetic acid (EDTA).
• Group 4: Orthophosphoric acid (H3PO4).
• Group 5: Photodynamic diode laser.

column2: • Glass fiber posts luted with self-adhesive resin cement.
• Push-out bond strength tested using a universal testing machine.
• Failure interfaces examined under stereomicroscope.
• Higher bond strength values for Helbo Theralite Laser and 37% orthophosphoric acid groups.
• Different smear layer removal methods affect bond strength (p<0.05).
• Photodynamic diode laser showed higher bond strength without smear layer removal.
• NaOCl and NaCl were not effective in removing smear layer.
• EDTA and H3PO4 were more effective in removing smear layer but laser and H3PO4 showed better bond strength.

column2: + *Causes*: Dermatophytes (e.g., Trichophyton rubrum, Trichophyton mentagrophytes), yeasts (e.g., Candida), and nondermatophytes.
+ *Prevalence*: Higher in toenails than fingernails, with dermatophytes accounting for 50-90% of cases.
+ *Risk Factors*: Aging, reduced peripheral circulation, diabetes, nail psoriasis.
+ *Complications*: Extension to other nails, further complications in at-risk patients.
+ *Difficulties*: Long treatment times, thick subungual hyperkeratosis limiting drug penetration.
+ *Limited Success*: Topical agents have limited success, new drugs with greater safety and rapid efficacy are needed.
+ *Study*: Open preliminary study in immunocompetent patients with toenail onychomycosis.
+ *Results*: Complete clinical healing in all patients after 12 weeks, with no side effects except for mild erythema in two patients.
+ *Mechanism*: Direct fungistatic activity, reduces hyperkeratinization, protects microvascular bed, and blocks fungal keratinolytic proteases.
+ *Potential*: Promising alternative for treatment-resistant forms or enhanced nail thickening, further studies needed to confirm long-term efficacy.
+ • **Clinical Non-Response to CRT**

column3: - Reported in 25-35% of patients

column2: + • **Causes for Suboptimal Response**

column3: - Selection of patients, inadequate delivery of therapy, etc.

column2: + • **Acute Haemodynamic Response (AHR) Study**

column3: - Studied in 24 non-consecutive patients who remained in NYHA class III/IV despite CRT and optimal medical therapy
- Patients underwent an acute haemodynamic study to improve existing CRT

column2: + • **Patient Characteristics**

column3: - 23 males, age 72.8 ± 9.1 years, mean ejection fraction 22.5 ± 7.1%
- ECG prior to implantation: left bundle branch block (LBBB) in 12, non-LBBB in 4, and right ventricular pacing in 8 patients

column2: + • **Acute Haemodynamic Study**

column3: - A 6F multipurpose angioplasty guiding catheter was introduced into the LV
- Endocardial pacing and measurements of LVdP/dtmax were accomplished using a Medtronic 6416 temporary bipolar screw-in lead and a radi pressure wire
- LV pacing was performed from basal posterolateral, mid-posterolateral, LV apical, and LV septal locations, and optimal AHR was obtained after optimization of the CRT system for all positions

column2: + • **Results**

column3: - 11 patients showed a positive response to endocardial pacing (apical in 7, anterolateral in 2, and mid-posterolateral in 2)
- 13 patients showed a negative response to endocardial pacing (basal posterolateral in 3, mid-posterolateral in 8, and apical in 2)
- 5 out of 9 acute haemodynamic non-responders with LBBB could increase AHR above the 15% level by LV endocardial pacing
- The average AHR with the coronary sinus system was 9.6% (5.8-14.9%), and at the LV endocardial optimal position, it was 25.8% (19.0-34.3%)

column1: * **Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) Patient Management**

column2: + *Prevalence and Progression*

column3: - Affects 1 in 500 to 1 in 1000 individuals
- May not manifest until third or fourth decade
- Half of patients progress to renal failure, with no predictable timeline for young patients

column2: + *Pregnancy Complications*

column3: - Maternal hypertension, preeclampsia, anemia, infected cysts, pyelonephritis, aneurysm rupture
- Hemodialysis required for renal failure management

column2: + *Patient Case*

column3: - 35-year-old primigravida with ADPKD, oligohydramnios, and renal insufficiency
- Underwent emergency LSCS with spinal anesthesia

column2: + *Anesthesia and Postoperative Care*

column3: - Successful spinal anesthesia with bupivacaine and fentanyl
- No neurological deficit, maintained normal hemodynamics, and no postoperative dialysis required

column2: + *Renal Function Changes*

column3: - Increased GFR and renal blood flow
- Serum creatinine > 0.8 mg/dL and BUN > 13 mg/dL suggest renal insufficiency

column2: + *ADPKD-specific Considerations*

column3: - Increased risk of hypertension and anemia
- Early dialysis recommended to prevent progression to end-stage renal disease

column2: + *Anesthesia and Hemodynamic Management*

column3: - Low-dose spinal anesthesia with intrathecal opioid to preserve renal and uterine blood flow
- Maintain adequate intravascular fluid volume and minimize cardiovascular depression

column2: + *Peak Milk Yield*

column3: - Normal cows: Peak at td-3 and td-4 (14.34-14.48 kg/d)
- Mastitis cows: Peak at td-3 (13.15 kg/d)

column2: + *Decline in Milk Yield*

column3: - Both groups: Steady decline after peak
- General trend: Increase till td-3, then decline

column2: + *Parity-wise Milk Yield*

column3: - First parity: Lower initial yield, higher persistency
- Fourth parity: Highest milk yield in both groups

column2: + *Initial Milk Yield (a)*

column3: - Normal cows: Higher than mastitis cows
- Peak in 4th parity, minimum in 1st parity

column2: + *Ascending Slope (b)*

column3: - Similar in 1st parity, declined in 2nd, increased in subsequent parities

column2: + *Descending Slope (c)*

column3: - Normal cows: Minimum in 1st, maximum in 4th parity
- Mastitis cows: Minimum in 1st, maximum in 5th and above parity

column2: + *Persistency*

column3: - Higher in 1st parity, declined till 5th and above parity

column2: + **Diet and Treatment**

column3: - Mice fed control diet or control diet supplemented with NDGA at 1.5, 2.5, 3.5, or 4.5 g/kg diet
- Food consumption and health monitored daily, body weight weekly

column2: + **Lifespan Results**

column3: - Median lifespan extended by 12% at 373 mg/kg bw/day (3.5 g/kg diet)
- No effect on maximum lifespan

column2: + **Pathology Findings**

column3: - Increased liver and lung tumors, enlarged thymuses, and hemorrhage into the peritoneum
- NDGA decreased liver tumor size but increased tumor number and prevalence of other tumors

column2: + **Treatment and Results**

column3: - Optimum oral treatment with NDGA at 3.0 mg/ml medium increased median lifespan by ~23%
- No effect on food consumption, body weight, or locomotor activity

column2: + **Toxicity**

column3: - No acute liver or kidney toxicity in mice
- Human studies show transaminitis at high doses

column2: + **Potential Mechanisms**

column3: - Inhibition of mTORC1 activity
- Hormetic stimuli and antioxidant properties unlikely to be major mechanisms
- Inhibition of oxidative phosphorylation not supported by data

column2: + * Genetic variation contributes to disease susceptibility and treatment response

column3: - Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have enabled rapid discovery of genetic variants
- Pharmacogenetic markers have been detected using GWAS

column2: + * Personalized medicine aims to improve medical decision-making

column3: - Includes optimal drug and dosage selection, preventive interventions, and targeted treatment options
- Examples: Prostate cancer treatment delay, hereditary cancer preventive surgery, anti-inflammatory therapies for inflammatory diseases

column2: + * Biomarkers are characteristics measured to influence, explain, or predict disease incidence or outcome

column3: - Types: Diagnostic, prognostic, predictive, safety, surrogate, target, toxicity, etc.
- Examples: Mammaprint, Oncotype DX, EGFR mutation test, IL28B gene test, etc.

column2: + * Biomarkers can be DNA, RNA, protein, metabolite, or epigenetic in nature

column3: - DNA biomarkers: Stable, reproducible, can be measured at any time, can be used in retrospective and prospective studies
- DNA tumor biomarkers: Cannot serve as surrogate markers, can show variation depending on measurement method
- General biomarkers: Can be quantitative, can serve as surrogate markers, can show variation over time

column2: + * Diagnostic and prognostic biomarkers can be validated using standard of care

column3: - Validation studies should follow appropriate reporting guidelines (STARD, STROBE-ME, REMARK, PRISMA, etc.)
- Retrospective validation studies can be performed using biobanks under certain conditions

column2: + * Predictive biomarkers must be closely linked to specific therapies for validation

column3: - Pivotal drug trials should consider ethnically homogenous populations for biomarker detection
- Clinical applications depend on ease of applicability, media for biomarker measurement, and clinician acceptance

column1: - - Driven by ATP hydrolysis and conformational change in motor domain
- - Lever arms amplify motion, taking 72 nm steps in a hand-over-hand fashion
- - Calcium required for ATP activity, but high calcium reduces processivity
- - Lever arms critical for processive movement and interhead communication
- - Lever arm/coiled-coil junction must be compliant for maneuverability
- - Distal rod domain has some effective length and contributes to stiffness
- - Globular tail domain interacts with motor domains and varies in apparent length
• **Tethered Particle Microscopy (TPM) for Measuring Flexural Stiffness:**
- - Anchors motor to microscope slide and attaches visible particle (qdot) to desired location
- - Thermal energy causes qdot displacement, measured by comparing image sizes
- - Long exposure times sample full extent of particle motion and reduce noise
- - Simultaneous estimation of flexural stiffness for multiple constructs
- - Lever arm stiffness estimated at 0.0346 pN/nm, with calcium reducing stiffness by 40%
- - Distal rod domain stiffness estimated at 0.0326 pN/nm, with unknown persistence length
- - Lever arm/rod junction highly compliant, contributing to myoVa maneuverability
- - Potential for calcium-dependent regulation of cargo transport and delivery

column2: + Determine if clinical outcome after surgical resection of esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) or esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) can be predicted by functional polymorphisms in proto-oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes.
+ Six single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in AURKA, ERBB2, MDM2, CDH1, CDKN2A, and TP73 genes were genotyped.
+ 346 esophageal cancer patients who underwent surgical resection with curative intent between 1996 and 2001.
+ Univariate analysis showed no significant associations between the tested polymorphisms and DFS in patients with EAC or ESCC.
+ Multivariate analysis revealed:

column3: - Patients with EAC carrying the heterozygous MDM2 (rs2279744) t/g genotype had significantly improved DFS compared to patients carrying the wild-type t/t genotype (adjusted hazard ratio (AHR) = 0.63, 95% CI [0.45-0.88], p = 0.007).

- Patients with EAC harboring the homozygous CDH1 (rs5030625) ga/ga genotype had a significantly reduced survival compared to patients carrying the wild-type g/g genotype (AHR = 4.0, 95% CI [1.4-11], p = 0.008).

column2: + MDM2 t/g genotype was associated with improved survival in EAC patients, possibly due to interaction with tumor TP53 status.
+ CDH1 ga/ga genotype was associated with reduced survival in EAC patients, potentially due to suppression of CDH1 gene expression and impairment of cell-cell adhesion.
+ Larger studies and genome-wide association studies are needed to validate the findings and identify additional polymorphisms associated with DFS in esophageal cancer patients.
+ Identification of high-risk patients could contribute to early detection of recurrent disease and personalized treatment strategies.

column1: - OPC is common in HIV patients, with over 90% developing it at some point.
- It is an opportunistic infection, more prevalent in patients with CD4+ counts below 200/mm³ or high viral load.
- OPC appears as erythematous patches or white, scrapable lesions.
- Fluconazole is the general treatment for OPC caused by C. albicans.
• Study on OPC and CD4+ Cell Counts
- A study evaluated OPC forms and their correlation with CD4+ cell counts in HIV patients.
- Most patients had CD4+ counts < 200 cells/mm³, and 73% of OPC cases were associated with this count.
• OPC is a significant clinical sign in HIV patients.
• Continued awareness and appropriate treatment are crucial due to the potential for resistant organisms.
• **Breast Cancer and Sentinel Lymph Node Biopsy (SLNB)**

column2: + • Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women, with approximately 1.67 million new patients diagnosed annually worldwide.
+ • SLNB is a standard method for determining axillary staging in early-stage breast cancer patients with a clinically and radiologically negative axilla.
+ • The combined technique of radioisotope and blue dye is currently used for SLNB, but it has drawbacks, including the use of radioisotopes and limited access in many hospitals.
+ • A magnetic tracer and a handheld magnetometer have been evaluated as a radiation-free alternative to the combined technique.
+ • Three different-sized superparamagnetic iron oxide (SPIO)-based formulations were evaluated in an in vivo porcine model for SLNB.
+ • The tracers used were Feraheme/Rienso (32 nm), Sienna+ (59 nm), and Endorem/Feridex (111 nm).
+ • All tracers were diluted to the same iron concentration (11.2 mg Fe/ml) for comparison.
+ • The hydrodynamic particle size of all tracers was determined using dynamic light scattering.
+ • A previously developed and validated porcine model was used to evaluate the performance of the different magnetic tracers for SLNB.
+ • Mini-pigs were injected with one of the three different magnetic tracers subcutaneously bilaterally into the areolas of the third inguinal mammary glands.
+ • Transcutaneous magnetometer measurements were undertaken in the inguinal region at various time points after administration of the tracer.
+ • Lymph nodes demonstrating SPIO uptake were removed, and the ex vivo magnetometer count was recorded.

+ • Sln identification was successful in all cases, with in vivo magnetic hotspots identified transcutaneously prior to surgical excision using the handheld magnetometer in all cases for the 32 nm and 59 nm tracers, and in all but one case for the 111 nm tracer.
+ • The number of procedures in which a transcutaneous hotspot was successfully identified increased with time after injection for all three tracers.
+ • A total of 77 slns were identified with the handheld magnetometer during surgery and subsequently excised, with the 32 nm tracer",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"

column1: * **Study on Serum Vaspin and Adiponectin Levels in Subjects with Normal Renal Function and Renal Insufficiency with or without Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus**

column2: + **Study Design**

column3: - Prospective study conducted in Shanghai, China
- Subjects: 416 individuals, divided into 4 groups based on the presence or absence of renal insufficiency (RI) and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM)
- Duration: June 2011 to December 2011

column2: + **Main Findings**

column3: - Serum vaspin levels were not significantly different between subjects with and without RI, regardless of T2DM status
- Serum vaspin levels were lower in patients with T2DM compared to non-diabetic individuals
- Serum adiponectin levels were higher in individuals with RI compared to those without, regardless of T2DM status

column2: + **Correlations and Associations**

column3: - Serum vaspin levels were correlated with creatinine clearance (CrCl), total cholesterol (TC), and hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) in all subjects
- Serum adiponectin levels were correlated with age, systolic blood pressure (SBP), CrCl, and HbA1c in all subjects
- After adjustment for age and body mass index (BMI), HbA1c was independently associated with serum vaspin levels, and CrCl was independently associated with serum adiponectin levels in all subjects

column2: • Two multicenter, double-blind, randomized clinical trials were used.
• Patients were diabetic (type 1 or 2), with Wagner grade 3 or 4 diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) larger than 1 cm.
• The trials compared recombinant human epidermal growth factor (rHEGF) at 75 and 25 µg with a placebo.
• Three area-based variables and granulation tissue formation were proposed as surrogates for complete healing.
• The median treatment duration was 5 weeks, and the end of treatment (EOT) data were used for comparison.
• Missing data were imputed using the last observation carried forward (LOCF) or the average between two contiguous evaluations.
• The area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve was calculated for each candidate surrogate variable.
• The product coefficient (PC) was used to quantify the contribution of the candidate surrogates to the final outcome.
• Granulation tissue covering >75% of the ulcer area at the EOT was the most efficient predictor of complete healing.
• The proportion mediated by granulation tissue formation was very high, suggesting that it plays a crucial role in healing.
• The models for final cicatrization and granulation surrogates fulfilled the Prentice criteria for a surrogate endpoint.
• Granulation tissue development can be used as a predictor of wound healing in advanced DFUs.
• This can be useful for clinical trial design and healthcare programs managing DFUs.
• The extrapolation of cutoff points for area-based surrogates requires further research.
• The larger sample of the postmarketing series could not be included due to it not being a controlled study.
+ Compare perioperative surgical trauma and its postoperative impact on the abdominal wall after N-TAPP and S-TAPP repair
+ Retrospective cohort study with institutional review board approval
+ 85 patients with single-sided primary inguinal hernia recruited between November 1, 2009, and July 31, 2012
+ Comparable at baseline between N-TAPP and S-TAPP groups
+ Male:Female ratio around 5:1
+ Age around 50 years
+ BMI around 25 kg/m²
+ Direct:Indirect:Pantaloon hernia ratio around 32:58:10%
+ Hernia diameter around 2.3-2.4 cm
+ N-TAPP: 8-mm umbilical trocar, 5-mm right trocar, 2-mm left trocar
+ S-TAPP: Gelpoint advanced-access platform with 5-mm optical and working trocars
+ Self-fixating Parietene ProGrip mesh used in both groups
+ Umbilical skin incision length: N-TAPP 13.4 mm vs. S-TAPP 27.3 mm (p < .001)
+ Operative time: N-TAPP 54.8 minutes vs. S-TAPP 85.9 minutes (p < .001)
+ Postoperative hospital stay: N-TAPP 1.8 days vs. S-TAPP 2.0 days (p = .21)
+ Immediate postoperative pain: N-TAPP 5.6 days vs. S-TAPP 9.8 days (p = .072)
+ Wound pain intensity: N-TAPP 2.7 VAS vs. S-TAPP 4.4 VAS (p = .016)
+ Abdominal wall mobility: N-TAPP 4.7 vs. S-TAPP 4.1 (p = .101)
+ Cosmetic satisfaction: N-TAPP 9.7 VAS vs. S-TAPP 9.6 VAS (p = .836)
+ Sick leave: N-TAPP 11.2",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: • **Breathing Process and Mouth Breathing in Children**

column2: + • Breathing begins at the upper airway and culminates in gas exchange inside the alveoli.
+ • Nose breathing prepares air for the lungs, warming, moistening, and filtering it, activating immunological processes.
+ • Mouth breathing in children can lead to pathological adaptations of the stomatognathic system, affecting facial growth and function.
+ • Hypertrophy of pharyngeal and/or palatine tonsils.
+ • Nasal mucosa and turbinate edema.
+ • Nasal septal deviation.
+ • Extended suction habits.
+ • Other causes.
+ • Morphological adaptations to facilitate air arrival to the alveoli.
+ • Functional changes in the stomatognathic system, affecting speech, chewing, and deglutition.
+ • Complex consequences associated with various etiologies, requiring multidisciplinary care.
+ • Otorhinolaryngologic exam for most causes.
+ • Nasopharyngoscopy for diagnosing pharyngeal hyperplasia.
+ • Cephalometry for assessing craniofacial growth and myofunctional status.
+ • Aimed to verify the correlation between nasopharyngoscopy and cephalometry in diagnosing hyperplasia of the pharyngeal tonsils.
+ • Found a regular and positive correlation between the two exams.
+ • Cephalometry tended to underestimate pharyngeal tonsil size compared to nasopharyngoscopy.
+ • Nasopharyngoscopy is the gold standard for assessing the nasopharynx.
+ • Cephalometry is a complementary exam that provides information about craniofacial growth.
+ • Children with mouth-breathing symptoms and normal radiography should be referred for nasopharyngoscopy.
• • Diagnosed with IDC at 35, treated with lumpectomy, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and hormone therapy
• • Developed inflammatory breast cancer in the same breast 4 years later, treated with chemotherapy and trastuzumab
• • Underwent breast reconstruction and remains in remission
• • IDC is the most common form of invasive breast cancer
• • Inflammatory breast cancer is rare and aggressive, requiring differential diagnosis
• • Treatment for IDC involves multidisciplinary approach, including surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and hormone therapy
• • IBTR can be either true local recurrence (TR) or new primary tumor (NPT)
• • TR and NPT have different natural histories, prognoses, and therapeutic implications
• • Salvage mastectomy is the standard treatment for IBTR, but further studies are needed to determine optimal treatment
+ AMD is a leading cause of severe vision loss in people aged 55 and older.
+ The neovascular form of AMD, involving choroidal neovascularization (CNV), accounts for most cases of AMD-related severe central vision loss.
+ Upregulation of angiogenic factors, including vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), is implicated in AMD development and progression.
+ Intravitreal anti-VEGF treatment is significantly more effective than previous alternatives in preventing progressive vision loss from neovascular AMD.
+ Ranibizumab (Lucentis) and Aflibercept (Eylea) are Health Canada-approved options for neovascular AMD treatment.
+ Monthly ranibizumab prevents vision loss in most patients with neovascular AMD, with significant visual gain achieved in some.
+ Intravitreal aflibercept injection every 8 weeks, following 3 initial monthly injections, is noninferior to monthly ranibizumab.
+ Aflibercept has a higher binding affinity to VEGF than ranibizumab, with a greater potency in vitro and a longer duration of action.
+ VA measures an individual's ability to identify fine detail at high contrast using black-on-white letters.
+ CS measures an individual's ability to detect low contrast images and perceive differences between light and dark.
+ CS can detect subtle vision changes that may be concealed by acuity and is a sensitive outcome end point for visual function and performance.
+ Both VA and CS are associated with the ability to perform daily vision-related activities and are significant independent parameters in determining visual impairment and quality of life.

column1: * **Study on Switching to Aflibercept from Ranibizumab in Recalcitrant Exudative AMD**

column2: + A single-center study evaluated the change from baseline to week 12 in Pelli-Robson CS as the primary clinical end point in patients with recalcitrant exudative AMD, despite previous ranibizumab treatment who were switched to aflibercept therapy.
+ Mean CS increased significantly from baseline to week 12, while mean VA was stable.
+ There was a statistically significant decrease in mean central retinal thickness (CRT) from baseline to week 12.

• Evaluate association between C424C/A polymorphism in IL-25 gene and Multiple Sclerosis (MS) in Iranian population
• Case-control study
• 74 MS patients (RRMS) and 75 healthy controls enrolled
• Based on Arababadi et al. study and sample size estimation formula
• 75 subjects in each group determined
• DNA purification from peripheral blood immune cells
• PCR amplification and RFLP of exon 2 of IL-25 gene
• Logistic regression model for statistical analysis
• No significant difference in genotype or allele frequencies between MS patients and controls
• No association between C424C/A polymorphism and MS risk
• C424C/A polymorphism in IL-25 gene not associated with MS risk
• Other polymorphisms in IL-25 gene may regulate its expression in MS

column1: • AA can be life-threatening and aorta size is the best criterion for intervention.
• Ascending thoracic aorta (ATA) most often results from cystic medial degeneration, while atherosclerosis is an infrequent cause.
• Thoracic AAs (TAAs) and abdominal AAs (AAAs) share common risk factors like age and hypertension.
• 542 consecutive Korean male hypertensive patients, aged 65 and above, were enrolled.
• Non-contrast CT of the whole aorta was performed using an Aquilion One 320-row CT system.
• Maximal diameters of ascending (ATAMAX), descending thoracic (DTAMAX), thoracic (TAMAX), and abdominal (AAMAX) aorta were measured.
• TAA was defined as TAMAX ≥40 mm and AAA as AAMAX ≥30 mm.
• Prevalence of TAA was 36.5% (181/496) and AAA was 6.0% (30/496).
• TAA was associated with older age, larger body surface area, higher diastolic blood pressure, absence of dyslipidemia, and presence of AAA.
• AAA was independently associated with dyslipidemia, current/past smoking, and presence of TAA.
• TAA was more prevalent than AAA in this high-risk population, but most TAAs were not large enough for immediate intervention.
• AAA was independently associated with smoking history in this Asian male population.
• The study's primary limitation was the inability to accurately measure the aortic root using non-contrast CT.
• Results may not be applicable to females, other ethnicities, or low-risk groups.

column2: • Endometrial cancer has surpassed cervical cancer as the most common invasive female genital tract malignancy in developed countries.
• Early screening methods for cervical cancer have been successful, and similar approaches are needed for endometrial cancer.
• Endometrial complex hyperplasia with atypia and endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia (EIN) are precursors of type I endometrioid adenocarcinoma.
• Endometrial glandular dysplasia is the precursor of type II carcinoma.
• Aim: Investigate the use of liquid-based SurePath preparation for endometrial cytology test (ECT) to maintain the three-dimensional structure of the endometrium.
• Method: Compare the adequacy of specimens obtained using the SAP-1 device with those obtained by dilation and curettage (D&C) or hysteroscopic biopsy.
• Study population: 1514 patients with endometrial cancer risk factors.

• Risk factors: Age, high estrogen levels, high BMI, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, family history of cancer, radiation and smoking history, abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB), and abnormal endometrium assessed by ultrasound.
• SAP-1 device provided more sufficient materials for cytology than D&C or hysteroscopic biopsy for histology (p < 0.01).
• Accuracy of cytology for detecting endometrial precursor and carcinoma was 91.7%, sensitivity 73.6%, specificity 94.9%, PPV 71.9%, and NPV 95.3%.
• D&C has low accuracy and causes discomfort.
• Other sampling devices like Tao Brush and Endoflower have inadequate sample rates ranging from 2% to 39%.
• Minimal pain during sampling.
• Avoids contamination from the endocervix and vagina.
• Procures an adequate representative sample of the entire endometrium.
• Safe, easy to use, and well-tolerated by patients.
• SAP-1 sampler combined with SurePath preparation may become a reliable method for screening endometrial carcinoma and its precursor, especially in postmenopausal and asymptomatic women.
• Early detection and management of precursors may be beneficial.
+ *Prevalence and Mortality:*

column3: - Most common cancer among women worldwide
- Highest incidence rates in Europe and North America

column2: + *Screening and Detection:*

column3: - Mammography screening reduces mortality by up to 50%
- Digital mammography (DM) is as efficacious as screen-film mammography (SFM)

column2: + *Overlapping Tissue:*

column3: - Breast cancers can be obscured by overlapping tissue
- Dense breast tissue reduces sensitivity of mammography

column2: + *False Positives:*

column3: - High false-positive rates lead to unnecessary recalls and biopsies
- Recall rates in the US are about twofold higher than in Europe

column2: + *Technique and Advantages:*

column3: - Uses X-rays to create thin image slices of breast tissue
- Improves visualization of breast anatomy and reduces tissue overlap

column2: + *Clinical Performance:*

column3: - Emerging evidence shows increased mammogram accuracy with DBT
- Potential to decrease recall rates and increase cancer detection

column2: + *Radiation Exposure:*

column3: - Overall radiation exposure is approximately the same as SFM or DM
- Synthetically reconstructed 2D images can reduce radiation dose

column2: + *Patient Comfort:*

column3: - Less compression may improve patient satisfaction
- DBT may reduce the need for additional mammogram views

column2: + *Interpretation Time:*

column3: - Longer interpretation times due to increased number of images
- Decreased recall rates and additional views may offset longer times

column2: + *Cost:*

column3: - DBT systems are more expensive than DM systems
- Potential cost savings from reduced biopsies and recalls

column2: + *Technique and Advantages:*

column2: + *Potential Applications:*

column1: • **Criticism and Evidence of OTC Cough and Cold Medications**

+ • Randomized, double-blind, crossover study with 22 adult nonsmokers with acute URI
+ • Significant increase in mean log C5 (cough reflex sensitivity) for diphenhydramine vs. placebo (p < 0.01)
+ • Further clinical trials needed to evaluate OTC cough and cold products
+ • Physicians and consumers can make informed decisions based on proper scientific data

column1: • **Axillary Lymph Node Status in Breast Carcinoma**

column2: + • Most important prognostic factor
+ • Worsens with increasing number of metastatic lymph nodes
+ • AJCC/UICC TNM classification
+ • Three groups based on number of axillary metastatic lymph nodes
+ • Depends on number of removed lymph nodes
+ • Difficult to assess reliably without sufficient lymph node removal
+ • Ratio of metastatic to removed lymph nodes
+ • Provides more useful prognostic information than nodal disease classification
+ • Vary in different studies
+ • Separate patients into low and high risk groups with significantly different survival
+ • Evaluated prognostic significance of number of removed and metastatic lymph nodes, and LNR
+ • Found that LNR is a powerful prognostic factor for distant metastasis development
+ • LNR can help standardize adjuvant therapy for patients operated in hospitals with different axillary dissection widths
+ • Useful for comparing treatment results from different hospitals
• Commonly activated by attachment of a good leaving group
• Conversion into an ester derivative of a strong acid (tosylate, mesylate, triflate)
• Mitsunobu or Appel conditions often employed
• Poor atom economy and large amounts of waste
• Catalytic processes made in the past decade
• Activation of hydroxy groups by enzymatic phosphorylation or sulfation
• ATP or PAPS used as cofactors
• ATP recycling feasible but PAPS not efficiently recycled
• Substrate-specificity limits broad synthetic applications
• Use of ATP-independent phosphatases with inorganic polyphosphates as donors
• Broad substrate spectrum and environmentally benign byproduct
• Reversibility of phosphate transfer requires kinetic control
• Transphosphorylation achieved in the late 1940s using phosphatase-enriched extracts
• Preparative-scale application decades later
• Acid phosphatases from enteric bacteria used for nucleoside phosphorylation

column1: • **Phosphatases in Drug Discovery and Synthetic Chemistry**

column2: • Phosphorylation as a prodrug strategy to enhance drug accessibility
• Phosphate di and triesters as Brønsted acid catalysts and leaving groups
• Phosphate monoesters underutilized due to insolubility in organic solvents
• Evaluate phosphatases for synthetic applications
• Enhance product titers and minimize hydrolytic reaction
• Phonse, Phonsf, and Piacp efficient in phosphorylating various alcohols
• Chemoselectivity for primary alcohols and o-nucleophiles
• Enantioselectivity not observed for most substrates
• Scale-up demonstrated using immobilized enzyme in flow mode

column2: • Aim: Compare stiffness of short-segment pedicle fixation using monoaxial or polyaxial screws in unstable burst fractures.
• Method: Used a calf experimental model with 12 fresh-frozen lumbar specimens (L1-L5).
• Groups: Monoaxial Pedicle Screw (MPS) and Polyaxial Pedicle Screw (PPS).
• Constructs:

column3: - 4-screw (MPS or PPS) with one vertebra above and one below the fracture.
- 6-screw (MPS or PPS with intermediate screws) with two screws at the fractured vertebra.

column2: • Intermediate screws decreased range of motion (ROM) in both MPS and PPS groups, indicating enhanced stability.
• Addition of intermediate screws significantly increased stiffness in flexion, extension, lateral bending, and torsion.
• MPS group had significantly greater stability in flexion and extension compared to PPS group.

column2: • • Originates from the area between notochord and foregut (pharyngeal endoderm)
• • Believed to be a remnant of embryonic communication between notochord and pharyngeal roof
• • Normally disappears during the second month of fetal development
• • Cystic type: develops if the embryonic remnant becomes obstructed
• • Crust type: forms if crusts adhere to the orifice without obstruction
• • Eagle (1939) indicated that in the crust type, the orifice is not obstructed despite crust formation

• • Symptoms: space-occupying lesion (nasal obstruction, Eustachian tube obstruction, dysphagia, cranial nerve paralysis) or rhinitis (choanal discharge, halitosis, pharyngitis, laryngitis, bronchitis, gastritis)
• • Incidence: approximately 4% in adults, peak incidence between 15 and 30 years, Caucasian predominance, no gender predilection
• • Most literature comprises selected case reports, describing the cystic type; no estimate for crust-type incidence or characterization of its symptoms
• • Aim: identify incidence, types, and clinical presentation of nasopharyngeal bursa disease over two years in a single rhinology practice
• • Method: clinicoanatomical audit of nasopharyngeal bursitis at a rhinology practice in a university unit during 2008-2009
• • Surgical technique: combined endonasal and transoral approach with electrocauterization for both cyst and crust types
• • Six patients diagnosed (four males, two females, mean age 54 years)
• • Incidence less than 1% of all rhinitis patients seen during the study period
• • Two patients with classical Tornwaldt's cyst, one with fibrosed cyst, three with crust-type bursitis
• • Classical cyst type: postnasal discharge, throat irritation, cough
• • Fibrosed type: incidentally discovered in a patient complaining of snoring
• • Crust type: crust expectoration, retching, fetid postnasal discharge, occasional occipital pain

column1: * **Incidence and Importance of Melanoma Skin Cancer**

column2: + Increasing incidence over past few decades
+ Estimated 76,250 new cases in USA in 2012
+ Estimated 9,180 deaths in USA in 2012
+ Australia has one of the highest rates of skin cancer in the world
+ Can spread widely over the body via lymphatic and blood vessels
+ Early diagnosis is key to prognosis
+ Dermoscopy is a non-invasive diagnostic technique for visualization of morphological features
+ Different techniques for dermoscopy, such as solar scan, epiluminescence microscopy (ELM), cross-polarization ELM (CPL-ELM), and side transillumination (TLM)
+ Improves diagnostic sensitivity by 10-30%
+ May lower diagnostic accuracy in hands of inexperienced dermatologists
+ Highly dependent on subjective judgement and scarcely reproducible
+ Several scoring systems and algorithms proposed to improve diagnostic performance
+ Growing interest in last two decades
+ Application of computational intelligence methods for faster data processing and better diagnoses
+ Studies on automated classification of pigmented skin lesion images since 1987
+ Importance of topic patent due to large quantity of research works
+ Numerous systems reported in literature using different border detection, feature extraction, selection, and classification algorithms
+ Some researchers reviewed and compared image analysis techniques for diagnosis of skin cancer
+ More research needed to identify and reduce uncertainties in automatic decision support systems
+ Comprehensive up-to-date review of automatic diagnostic model for skin lesions not available
+ Based on semantic analysis of melanoma images and classification of characteristic objects
+ Aim: summarize and compare advanced dermoscopic algorithms, discuss important issues affecting classification success
+ Brief and comprehensive review of feature extraction and selection algorithms
+ Analysis of various papers based on several criteria, such as lesion segmentation, feature extraction, size of data sets, classification techniques, and performance measures

+ Aim: Assess impact of PON1 (Q192R) and CYP2C19*2 polymorphisms on clopidogrel platelet inhibition
+ Design: North American study population of mixed racial background with established coronary disease on dual antiplatelet therapy
+ Methods: Light transmittance aggregometry (LTA) and VerifyNow (VN) P2Y12 assay
+ 151 patients on maintenance clopidogrel therapy or received 600 mg loading dose during PCI
+ Well-balanced clinical variables among genotype groups
+ Higher prevalence of African Americans in PON1 QQ192 carriers
+ No significant deviations from Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium
+ No CYP2C19*3 alleles detected
+ Wide interindividual variability during clopidogrel therapy
+ PON1 QQ192 not associated with increased platelet aggregation or VN P2Y12 reactivity
+ CYP2C19*2 carriers had higher platelet aggregation and lower VN platelet inhibition
+ No significant difference in platelet inhibition among PON1 genotypes
+ No significant difference in platelet aggregation or inhibition among PON1 genotypes
+ CYP2C19*2 carriers had significantly lower percentage of platelet inhibition
+ Univariate: CYP2C19*2 carrier status, current smoking, and weight associated with ADP-induced platelet aggregation
+ Multivariate: CYP2C19*2 carrier status associated with ADP-induced platelet aggregation, PON1 Q192R not significant
+ CYP2C19*2 polymorphism associated with reduced platelet inhibition by clopidogrel
+ PON1 Q192R polymorphisms not predictive of clopidogrel response in patients with coronary artery disease

column3: - 34-year-old female with medically intractable seizures
- History of hydrocephalus and ventriculoperitoneal shunting
- Decreased visual acuity due to chorioretinitis

column2: + *Diagnosis*

column3: - Positive Toxoplasma-specific IgG test, negative IgM (chronic phase)
- Brain MRI showed left hippocampal sclerosis, amygdala hypertrophy, and multifocal calcifications

column2: + *Seizure Characteristics*

column3: - Psychic aura (anxiety) followed by dialeptic seizure and secondary generalization
- Left temporal onset with rhythmic delta and theta activity

column2: + *Presurgical Evaluation*

column3: - Video-EEG monitoring confirmed left temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE)
- SPECT and FDG-PET showed left mesial temporal hyperperfusion/hypermetabolism
- Wada test revealed right hemisphere language and memory dominance

column2: + *Epilepsy Surgery*

column3: - Left anteromesial temporal resection including calcified lesion
- Predicted good outcome due to right hemisphere language and memory dominance

column2: + *Toxoplasmosis and Epilepsy Association*

column3: - Congenital toxoplasmosis can cause multifocal calcifications and CNS damage
- HS in TLE may be caused by initial precipitating illness, inflammation, or coincidence

• Evaluate characteristics and determinants of partial remission (PR) in type 1 diabetes (T1D) using a new definition.
• Investigate correlations between PR and long-term T1D evolution, complications, and severe hypoglycemia.
• Retrospective study of 242 children diagnosed with T1D between 1994 and 2008, followed until adulthood.
• PR defined as insulin-dose adjusted A1C (IDAA1C) ≤ 9%.
• PR occurred in 56.2% of patients, with no cases of complete remission.
• No significant gender difference in PR occurrence.
• Lower A1C at diagnosis associated with higher chances of PR.
• No DKA at diagnosis associated with higher chances of PR, especially in boys.
• Higher baseline C-peptide concentrations in PR patients, more pronounced in boys.
• Mean PR duration of 9.2 months, with 71.6% of patients experiencing PR for less than 1 year.
• Lower A1C levels at 3 to 12 months associated with longer PR durations.
• No long-term effects of PR on diabetes complications or severe hypoglycemia, but a short-term effect on metabolic control in patients with PR durations between 510 and 570 days.
• No significant differences in anti-GAD65 and anti-IA2 antibody titers among different populations.
• PR duration shorter in patients with 2 positive autoantibodies compared to those with 1 positive antibody.
• Older children at diagnosis had higher C-peptide levels after 2 years.
• Low numbers of events limited the analysis of long-term effects of PR on complications and severe hypoglycemia.
• Further long-term research needed to determine if the short-term effect of PR on metabolic control is associated with a reduced rate of complications and severe hypoglycemia.

column1: * **Oral Health Importance and Prevalence of Lesions**

column2: + Oral health is crucial for quality of life in all age groups.
+ Oral lesions can interfere with daily activities and social interactions.
+ Prevalence of oral lesions in the elderly is high and varies by region and socioeconomic factors.
+ The study was conducted on 5,100 geriatric patients in India.
+ 64% of patients presented with various oral lesions.
+ Males were more affected than females, but the difference was not statistically significant.
+ Nicotinic stomatitis (43%) and denture stomatitis (34%) were the most common lesions.
+ Oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF) was also prevalent (30%) due to betel nut chewing.
+ Squamous cell carcinoma was diagnosed in 2% of patients.
+ Age, tobacco use, and poorly adapted prostheses increase the odds of having oral lesions.
+ Certain lesions are more common on specific sites, like hard palate (23.1%) and soft palate (3.6%).
+ There was a slight male preponderance in lesion prevalence.
+ The study provides valuable information for future oral health studies in India's geriatric population.
+ Community programs should educate and screen the elderly for oral-mucosal lesions.
+ Planning is needed in social, economic, and health-related areas due to the increasing aged population.

column1: • Rare osseous tumor (<1% of primary bone tumors)
• Affects epiphyseal regions of tubular bones, especially tibia, femur, and humerus
• Uncommon in head and neck region, but can occur in temporal bone or temporomandibular joint (TMJ)
• Can cause occlusal abnormalities, trismus, clicking of TMJ, hearing impairments, dizziness, and otorrhea
• Malignant changes can occur after irradiation
• Radiation therapy should be avoided due to risk of malignant progression
• Unusual histological features in temporal bone make diagnosis difficult
• Incomplete resection carries a high risk of recurrence
• 41-year-old male with TMJ disorder initially diagnosed with otitis media
• Chronic hearing loss, trismus, and dizziness
• Tumor mass in middle cranial fossa, including TMJ and cochlea
• Delayed accurate diagnosis due to insufficient imaging and histopathologic examination
• Complete surgical removal for curative treatment
• Modified surgical procedure to preserve facial function and prevent postoperative TMJ dysfunction
• No residual tumor or recurrence four and a half years after surgery
• No postoperative irradiation due to contraindication with chondroblastoma diagnosis

column2: + Aim: To evaluate whether levels of accurately quantified sedentary behavior and habitual physical activity could predict levels of visceral adipose tissue (VAT) and intrahepatic lipid (IHL) in adults with overweight/obesity.
+ Hypotheses:

column3: - Negative relationship between time spent in moderate intensity physical activity and levels of VAT and IHL.
- Positive relationship between time spent in sedentary behavior and VAT and IHL content.
- Sedentary behavior and moderate physical activity would explain a significant proportion of variance in VAT and IHL when modeled with known obesity-related health risk factors.

column2: + Traditional risk factors (e.g., sex, age, waist circumference) were associated with VAT and IHL, but no relationship was observed between objectively measured physical inactivity and raised liver fat.
+ Unexpected positive association between VAT volume and time spent in moderate activity, and total energy expenditure.

+ Inclusion of objectively measured levels of moderate activity and sedentary behavior did not improve the potency of traditional risk factors for predicting liver fat concentration or level of visceral adiposity.
+ * Retrospective, observational, consecutive case series
+ * Conducted in a tertiary eye care hospital in North India
+ * Included patients with fireworks-related injuries over 5 days of Diwali festival from 2011 to 2015
+ * Total of 53 eyes of 45 patients were seen
+ * More severe ocular damage among patients who ignited fireworks themselves
+ * 9.43% had open-globe injury, 90.56% had closed-globe injury
+ * 33.96% eyes underwent surgical management, 64.15% were managed conservatively
+ * 5 eyes developed phthisis bulbi, 1 eye was advised primary enucleation
+ * Vision outcomes varied, with 22 eyes having BCVA of 6/6 at final follow-up
+ *Definition*: SCH is defined as an isolated elevation of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels with a normal free thyroxine (FT4) level.
+ *Prevalence*: SCH is relatively common, with a prevalence ranging from 4% to 20% in the adult population, affecting women, elderly people, and iodine-sufficient populations more often.

column1: * **Association of SCH with Cardiovascular Disease (CVD) and Other Health Outcomes**

column2: + *CVD Risk Factors*: SCH is associated with increased blood pressure, altered lipid levels, and enhanced weight gain, which can lead to vascular problems and endothelial dysfunction.

+ *CVD and Mortality*: Studies have shown that SCH may be associated with a modest increase in the risks of coronary heart disease and mortality, particularly in subjects with higher TSH levels. However, the association remains controversial, and more research is needed.

column1: • • Rare genodermatosis with progressive adnexal skin tumors in scalp and face
• • Due to mutations in the tumor suppressor gene CYLD on chromosome 16q12q13
• • Low risk of malignancy, requires long-term follow-up
• • 71-year-old woman with progressive asymptomatic lesions in her head for 4 years
• • Multiple rounded skin-colored or erythematous papules, 28 mm in diameter, located in scalp and forehead
• • Histopathological diagnosis: spiradenomas and one cylindroma
• • Family history: lesions in mother, her brother, and two daughters
• • Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern suggested by family pedigree
• • Heterozygous mutation c.1628_1629delct in CYLD gene found in patient and two affected daughters
• • Wild-type genotype in unaffected daughter and her children
• • Progressive development of adnexal skin tumors in scalp and face, starting from puberty
• • Higher incidence in females, no racial distinction
• • Increased risk of salivary glands neoplasms and other tumors
• • Cylindromas and spiradenomas have different locations and expressions
• • Genetic counseling offered to first-degree relatives, with 50% probability of descendants developing BSS

column2: + Detected more than 25 years ago, now important nosocomial pathogens
+ Mediated by van genes, with vanA and vanB being most prevalent
+ Rising incidence in several European countries, including Denmark
+ Estimated carrier-to-infection ratio of up to 10:1
+ Screening relies on selective culturing and/or detection of vanA or vanB genes by PCR
+ Rapid results can lead to substantial indirect savings
+ Xpert vanA/vanB assay used in the study, providing results within an hour
+ Serves a population of 800,000 in the northern part of the Danish capital region
+ Four university hospitals with 1577 beds and three intensive care units
+ Infection control units employ six infection control nurses
+ Comparison of culture-based method and PCR using the Xpert vanA/vanB assay
+ 1110 samples examined, 13.8% vanA PCR positive, 15.2% culture positive for vanA phenotype
+ 22.5% vanB PCR positive, but only 0.1% culture positive for vanB phenotype
+ Xpert vanA/vanB assay showed excellent diagnostic accuracy for vanA detection
+ PCR-based screening saved 141 isolation days and 292 transmission risk days
+ • Local tissue/cellular RAAS plays important roles in cardiovascular diseases
+ • Aldosterone and mineralocorticoid receptor (MR) activation contribute to hypertension and heart failure
+ • MR antagonists show significant benefits in patients with left ventricular dysfunction and myocardial infarction
+ • Benefits of MR blockade in diabetes are unclear
+ • Signaling network alterations in diabetes require tailored therapies
+ • ACE inhibitors (ACEi) and angiotensin type-1 receptor blockers (ARBs) protect against end-organ damage but do not completely block it
+ • Characterize and compare effects of RAAS inhibitors on ischemia/reperfusion (I/R)-induced cardiac dysfunction in normal and diabetic rats
+ • Identify optimal drug combinations and timing (before or after ischemia)
+ • Ru28318 (Ru, selective MR antagonist), captopril (Capt, ACEi), losartan (Los, ARB)
+ • Single, double, and triple therapy combinations administered before or after ischemia
+ • Ru resulted in the most rapid recovery in coronary flow (CF) and left ventricular developed pressure (LVDP) when given before ischemia
+ • Capt + Los therapy given before ischemia resulted in rapid improvement in LVDP and CF
+ • Triple therapy (Capt + Los + Ru) yielded the best recovery in LVDP and CF when given before or after ischemia
+ • Capt + Los double therapy yielded the best improvement in LVDP when given before or after ischemia
+ • Ru alone was ineffective at improving LVDP when given after ischemia in diabetes
+ • Triple combination was generally the most effective strategy in preventing or reversing I/R-induced cardiac dysfunction in normal or diabetic hearts
+ • Ru alone could be an effective therapy for prevention of cardiac dysfunction in normal patients
+ • ACEi and/or ARBs appear to be the drugs of choice for postischemic injury in diabetic patients
+ • MR antagonists may represent a novel class of RAAS inhibitor that could overcome limitations of ACEi and ARB combinations

column1: • **Cardiovascular Disease (CVD) and N-3 Polyunsaturated Fatty Acids (N-3 PUFAs)**

column2: + • CVD is a leading cause of mortality, with increasing incidence.

column3: - • Atherosclerosis, hypertension, dyslipidemia, chronic inflammation, and insulin resistance are key risk factors.
- • N-3 PUFAs have proven beneficial effects in preventing these risk factors.
- • Their lipid-lowering, anti-inflammatory, antithrombotic, antiatherosclerotic, and antiarrhythmogenic effects are well-documented.

column2: + • N-3 PUFAs are classified into two families: omega-3 (n-3) and omega-6 (n-6), with distinct locations of the last double bond.

column3: - • The human body can produce almost all fatty acids except linoleic acid (LA, C18:2n-6) and alpha-linolenic acid (ALA, C18:3n-3), which are essential fatty acids.

- • ALA is a precursor to eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) in the n-3 family, while LA is a precursor to dihomo-γ-linolenic acid (DGLA) and arachidonic acid (AA) in the n-6 family.
- • The conversion of ALA to EPA and DHA is limited, and tissue and circulating EPA and DHA levels are primarily related to dietary intake, with fish being the major food source.

column1: • **EPA and DHA: Differential Effects and Mechanisms of Action**

column2: + • EPA and DHA have distinct effects on cardiovascular health, with DHA showing more potent antiarrhythmic and heart rate-lowering effects than EPA.

column3: - • DHA incorporation into myocardial cell membranes influences membrane fluidity, channel activities, and the beta-adrenergic system, contributing to its antiarrhythmic and hypotensive effects.
- • DHA stimulates ATP release from endothelial cells, increasing vasodilation and potentially contributing to its blood pressure-lowering effect.
- • EPA and DHA both reduce triglyceride levels, with DHA showing a more significant reduction in some studies.

column2: • Aimed to compare functional and anatomical outcomes of bevacizumab vs. ranibizumab in treating neovascular age-related macular degeneration (nAMD) in Turkish patients.
• Retrospective study of patients treated between 2009 and 2011, with a minimum follow-up of 12 months.
• Inclusion criteria: age ≥50, newly diagnosed nAMD, no prior treatments, minimum follow-up of 12 months.
• Exclusion criteria: other retinal diseases, previous intravitreal injections, photodynamic therapy, or laser photocoagulation.
• As-needed treatment regimen with monthly doses for the first three months, then retreated if certain criteria were met.
• Bevacizumab: 1.25 mg/0.05 mL, Ranibizumab: 0.5 mg/0.05 mL.
• Best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) and central retinal thickness (CRT) at baseline, months 3, 6, 9, 12, and most recent follow-up.
• Number of injections at month 12.
• Both drugs showed significant improvement in BCVA and CRT from baseline at all time points.
• No significant difference between the two groups in BCVA, CRT, or number of injections at month 12.
• No serious ocular or systemic complications observed in any patient.

column3: - SHP associated with lower birth weight, fetal growth restriction, NICU admission, and preterm delivery

column2: • Prevalent in southern regions, particularly in Hormozgan province
• P. vivax is the dominant species (90-95% of cases)
• Iran entered the malaria pre-elimination program in 2009
• Bagh-e Malek region in Minab district, Hormozgan province
• 200 healthy volunteers (62 males, 138 females) aged 3 to 60 years
• Microscopy (gold standard)
• Rapid Diagnostic Tests (RDTs)
• Nested-PCR (sensitive and specific)
• No positive cases detected by microscopy or RDTs
• 3 asymptomatic P. vivax cases detected by nested-PCR (1.5%)
• All positive cases were females, one with a history of malaria 20 years ago
• Detects asymptomatic carriers, mixed infections, and sub-clinical parasitaemia
• Complementary to microscopy and RDTs in active case surveillance
• Use all three detection tools (microscopy, RDTs, and molecular methods) for improved sensitivity, specificity, and reliability
• Essential for malaria elimination and prevention of re-introduction in Iran
+ Many new immunotherapy approaches have entered clinical development due to increased understanding of immune mechanisms.
+ Some agents have been approved, like infusional cytokine therapies, intravesical BCG therapy, and sipuleucel-T for prostate cancer.
+ Other agents, like ipilimumab for advanced melanoma, have shown benefit in large clinical trials and are anticipated for approval.
+ Combination therapies present challenges for evaluating these agents using traditional clinical development paradigms.
+ Antigen-specific vaccines have been relatively straightforward to evaluate using immune responses to target antigens as biomarkers.
+ However, target antigen immune response has not always been associated with clinical benefit.
+ Broadly active immune modulating agents, like T-cell checkpoint inhibitors, have more elusive biomarkers of response.

+ Studies with anti-CTLA-4 monoclonal antibodies have sought to identify useful biomarkers, such as amplification of other T-cell costimulatory molecules or antibodies to defined antigenic tumor-associated proteins.

column1: * **Using SEREX-Based Studies to Identify Prostate Cancer-Associated Antigens**

column2: + SEREX-based studies have identified hundreds of immunologically recognized proteins associated with prostate tissue and/or recognized by patients with prostate cancer.
+ These antigens might have diagnostic value in distinguishing individuals with prostate cancer from men without prostate disease.

+ A subset of 23 antigens was recognized in patients with prostate cancer as well as individuals with symptomatic prostatitis, suggesting potential use in identifying inflammatory conditions of the prostate.
+ The study hypothesized that a panel of previously identified prostate-associated antigens could be used as a monitoring tool to assess immune responses following immune-modulating therapy.
+ IgG responses were measured using a phage immunoblot approach, and machine-learned Bayesian belief networks (ML-BBNs) were used to identify potentially promising biomarkers.
+ The study found that IgG immune responses could be detected to individual antigens and were associated with specific treatments.
+ ML-BBN models were used to identify groups of IgG responses associated with clinical response (PSA decline) at three months following treatment.

column1: • Study conducted in the departments of oral medicine and radiology and a cancer center.
• Total sample of 90 individuals: 60 oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) patients and 30 healthy controls.
• OSCC patients were between 25 and 75 years, with histologically proven oral cancer but before treatment.
• Controls were healthy volunteers aged 25-75 years with no history of systemic illness or tobacco/alcohol consumption.
• Serum L-fucose level estimated using Winzler method on clinical chemistry autoanalyzer.
• Statistical analysis: Independent samples t-test for two groups, one-way ANOVA for three or more groups.
• Mean serum L-fucose level in OSCC patients (10.85 mg/dL) vs. healthy controls (3.47 mg/dL), p < 0.001.
• Progressive increase in L-fucose levels with cancer stage (I to IV): 8.13, 9.18, 10.53, and 11.59 mg/dL, respectively, p < 0.001.
• L-fucose is a monosaccharide involved in cell-to-cell communication and signaling pathways.
• Increased fucosylation levels in tumor cells contribute to decreased adhesion and uncontrolled growth.
• Estimating serum L-fucose levels could be a promising approach for early detection, diagnosis, and prognosis of various cancer types, including oral cancer.
• **Correlation with Histopathological Grading and TNM Stages**
• No significant correlation between serum L-fucose levels and histopathological grading (age and gender).
• Positive correlation between serum L-fucose levels and TNM stages of OSCC.
• Serum L-fucose level elevation not specific to oral cancer; other degenerative and proliferative diseases can also cause elevation.
• Further investigation on a larger scale is needed to confirm serum L-fucose as an effective tumor marker in oral cancer diagnosis and management.

+ Potential anti-inflammatory role in metabolic regulation

column2: + *Findings*

column3: - Total of 73 cases, with a boys-to-girls ratio of 2.32
- Four different bacteria isolated: E. coli (64.4%), Enterobacter (19.2%), Klebsiella, and S. epidermidis
- E. coli mostly resistant to ampicillin (93.6%), cefixime, and cephalexin; most susceptible to norfloxacin and ciprofloxacin

column2: + *Implications and Recommendations*

column3: - E. coli was the most prevalent organism causing UTI in neonates
- Continuous assessment of uropathogen epidemiology crucial for empirical therapy choice
- Third-generation cephalosporins plus an aminoglycoside recommended as first-line empiric therapy for neonatal UTIs

column1: - Most frequent CAH variant, accounting for 95% of all affected patients
- Three clinical forms: classical (salt-wasting and simple virilizing), and non-classical
- Inactivating mutations in the CYP21A2 gene leading to 21-hydroxylase deficiency
- Decreased negative feedback to the HPA axis, adrenal gland hyperplasia, and increased virilization
- Glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement therapy to prevent adrenal crises and suppress androgen secretion
- Potential over- or under-suppression leading to various complications, such as Cushing's syndrome, obesity, growth suppression, and adrenal tumors
- White matter changes and temporal lobe structures dysgenesis in CAH patients due to 21-OHD
- White matter hyperintensities, temporal lobe atrophy, and hippocampal dysgenesis observed in MRI studies
- Potential causes: hormonal imbalances during early development and exposure to excess exogenous glucocorticoids

column2: • • The human genome sequence promises significant biomedical advances.
• • Biologists must navigate vast genomic data to uncover knowledge.
• • Different communities use varying definitions of 'function'.
• • Two common methods for annotating genes: experimental and evolutionary.
• • Experimental annotation is limited to characterized genes.
• • Evolutionary annotation uses homology to predict function.
• • Domains are homologous portions of protein sequences.
• • Domain architectures predict protein function and evolution.
• • Automatic annotation using domains is efficient but not definitive.
• • High-throughput studies and model organisms will enhance annotation.
• • Domain-based methods will remain useful until better alternatives are available.
• • Comparative proteomics aids in understanding evolution and function.
• • Web-based resources provide multi-faceted views of genomic data.
• • Gene Ontology project aims to standardize functional descriptions.
• • Orthology prediction and domain subfamily partitioning aid navigation.
• • The human genome is currently sparsely annotated.
• • Future progress will require integration of vast datasets.
• • Success of genome projects will be measured by new research and therapies.
+ Compare four commercially available online heart rate monitoring systems
+ Evaluate systems in a field test against each other
+ Assess operating distance and validity against a commercially available ECG
+ Evaluate installation and use of software and hardware
+ 12 active people (11 men and 1 woman)
+ Age: 26.4 ± 3.2 years
+ Height: 177.9 ± 8.7 cm
+ Mass: 78 ± 7 kg
+ Polar Team Pro
+ Acentas Team Monitoring System
+ Suunto Pro Team Pack
+ Activio Sport System
+ Subdivided into three main categories: measurement, software, and hardware
+ Measurement represented by 200 scores out of 500
+ Hardware and software equally divided into 150 scores each
+ Measurement of failure ratio during a real soccer match
+ Distance measurement on an uphill street
+ Comparison against ECG in a laboratory
+ Acentas and Polar led in hardware category
+ Activio offered the most harmonious software concept
+ Acentas had the highest operating distance (349 m)
+ Polar had the lowest failure quota (0.6%)
+ Each system has its advantages and disadvantages depending on the use
+ Study can be used for further system improvements
+ No single system can be recommended

column3: - Ability to make identical copies of themselves

column3: - Permit isolation by flow cytometry, magnetic bead isolation, etc.

column3: - Relative quiescence of lung epithelia

column2: + *Identified stem cell populations*

column2: + *Cancer stem cell hypothesis*

column3: - Relatively rare, multipotent cells drive tumor growth
- Heterogeneity within tumors due to aberrant differentiation
- Chemoresistance and poor prognosis linked to cancer stem cells

column2: + *Targeted therapies*

column3: - Potential for improved delivery using agents directed at cell of origin
- Specific targeting of lung cancer stem cells or pathways conferring stem cell-like properties

column2: + *Unanswered questions*

column3: - Role of healthy adult stem cells vs. de-differentiated cells in tumorigenesis
- Relationship between tumor microenvironment and lung cancer stem cells

column1: • **Study on Tip Urethroplasty for Hypospadias in Yemen**
• 100 children with primary anterior penile hypospadias
• Urethral plate width > 8 mm (Group A) or < 8 mm (Group B)

• Tip urethroplasty has good cosmetic and functional results

column1: * **Findings on T. vaginalis infection among Peruvian women**

column2: + *Prevalence and risk factors*

column3: - Overall prevalence: 21.4%
- Older age, lower education, single status, unprotected sex with non-steady partners, multiple sex partners

column2: + *Syndromic management and asymptomatic nature*

column3: - No association between vaginal symptoms and T. vaginalis infection
- Syndromic management may result in over- and under-treatment
- Asymptomatic nature contributes to long duration and spread of infection

column2: + *Target population and core group for endemic infections*

column3: - Hard-to-reach, socially marginalized populations often underrepresented in healthcare settings
- High-risk target population for reproductive health complications

column2: + *Need for screening, treatment, and partner notification*

column3: - Improved disease control activities to reduce adverse reproductive health outcomes
- Further studies to determine if screening and treatment improve reproductive health and birth outcomes
- Prioritize screening and treatment of sex partners to prevent reinfection and reduce infection prevalence

column2: + *Seizure Types*

column3: - Tonic, atonic, and atypical absence seizures are most common
- Some patients also develop myoclonic, generalized tonic-clonic, or partial seizures

column2: + *Diagnostic Features*

column3: - Interictal awake EEG pattern of slow spike wave discharges (<3 Hz)
- Paroxysms of low voltage fast activity (10 Hz) during sleep
- Cognitive impairment involving moderate to severe mental retardation and behavioral disorders

column2: + *Treatment Challenges*

column3: - Difficult to treat due to encephalopathic nature and multiple seizure types
- Many drugs reduce seizures initially but lose effectiveness over time

column2: + *Rufinamide*

column3: - Well-tolerated and efficacious for seizures in LGS
- Decreases total seizures and tonic-atonic seizures compared to placebo
- Well-tolerated with minimal side effects, but further studies needed to establish its role in treatment algorithm

column2: + Iberian wall lizards (Podarcis hispanica) use chemical signals for interpopulational recognition and premating reproductive isolation.
+ Differences in chemical signals between populations may lead to reduced gene flow and cryptic speciation.
+ Five distinct populations of Iberian wall lizards in central Spain differ in morphology and chemical signals.
+ Males and females can recognize and discriminate between scents of individuals from different populations.
+ Some populations may exhibit reproductive isolation and cryptic speciation, but further studies are needed.
