• Rubella infection during early pregnancy has a 90% chance of passing the virus to the fetus.
• CRS is the most important complication, caused by lack of immunity during pregnancy.
• Vaccination prevents maternal infection and CRS, affecting around 110,000 infants annually in developing countries.
• The primary goal of rubella vaccination is to prevent congenital infection and CRS.
• The most commonly used vaccine is derived from the RA27/3 virus strain, inducing seroconversion in 95% of vaccinated persons.
• Vaccination policies and studies have significantly decreased rubella cases and increased immunity in various countries and regions.
• Iran implemented a national rubella vaccination program in 2003, targeting 5 to 25-year-olds.
• The program successfully reduced measles and rubella cases to less than one case per million.
• A study in Kermanshah showed a significant rise in seropositivity and immunity against rubella in vaccinated girls (99.3%) compared to unvaccinated girls (79.6%).
• Screening for rubella immunity should be conducted every few years, especially for vulnerable groups like pregnant women.
• Similar studies should be conducted for other vaccines, such as tetanus and diphtheria.
• Regular rubella seroepidemiology studies should be performed every couple of years to monitor immunity status and vaccinate vulnerable individuals if necessary.

column1: • **Advent of Cell Type Specific Molecular Markers**

column2: + • Enables description and analysis of developmental morphogenesis in biological systems
+ • Gene-specific RNA probes used for visualization of gene expression patterns
+ • Whole mount in situ hybridization (WISH) technique initially used with radioactive probes, later simplified with nonradioactive probes
+ • Widespread use in various biological systems, including Drosophila, Xenopus, Quail, Dictyostelium, and Zebrafish
+ • Diverse uses, including medical and prenatal diagnostics
+ • Difficult to discern overlapping regions of expression
+ • Fluorescent methods offer potential solution
+ • Limited use in systems other than Drosophila and Zebrafish
+ • Quality of fluorescent images insufficient and autofluorescence interference

column1: • **Advantages of Quantum Dots (QDs) for In Situ Hybridization**

column2: + • Strong fluorescent signal emission compared to organic and protein fluorophores
+ • Longer excited state lifetime for background fluorescence separation
+ • Wide excitation spectra, narrow and tunable emission spectra, large separation between excitation and emission, and resistance to photobleaching
+ • Ideal candidate for detecting multiple mRNAs inISH protocols and high fluorescence intensity for RNA detection in whole embryos

column1: • **Penetration Issues with QDs in Xenopus Embryos**

column2: + • Commercially available QDs are large and fail to penetrate many cell layers of an embryo or are significantly trapped
+ • Proteinase K treatment renders Xenopus embryos permeable to QD penetration
+ • QDs can penetrate deep within embryonic tissues and provide specific deep tissue staining
+ • Proteinase K treatment not suitable for most whole-mount immunostaining antibodies due to target antigen degradation

column1: • **Successful Implementation of QD-Based WISH in Xenopus Embryos**

column2: + • QD detection of endogenous messenger RNAs is effective and provides higher resolution than current techniques
+ • Two-color in situ hybridization can be performed simultaneously using QDs
+ • QD-based WISH in Xenopus embryos suggests successful applications in most developmental models
+ • QD in situ staining remains localized and fluorescent for more than an hour after embryo clearing
+ Pancreatic cancer has the highest mortality and lowest survival rates among all cancers.
+ Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is the most common subtype, with a median survival of about four months.
+ Several demographic and clinical factors significantly impact PDAC survival, including:

column3: - Gender, race, age at diagnosis, marital status, and time period of diagnosis.
- Tumor size, nodal status, and distant metastases.
- Surgical resection of the tumor, with or without adjuvant chemotherapy and radiation.

column2: + Cox proportional hazards regression models were used to estimate survival for PDAC patients.
+ Two nomograms were developed for patients who underwent pancreatectomy and for predicting perioperative mortality.
+ Two new Cox regression models were developed for resectable and unresectable PDAC, leading to an interactive online clinical calculator.
+ A web-based, real-time prognostic tool was developed using SEER data on 18,352 pathologically confirmed PDAC cases diagnosed between 2004 and 2009.
+ The tool estimates survival and conditional survival probabilities, along with their corresponding standard errors.
+ The tool's reliability and generalizability were proven by calibration and discrimination abilities, validated using internal and external datasets.
• • Recruited 278 CLI patients undergoing primary PTA procedures between 2003 and 2009 at Kansai Rosai Hospital, Hyogo, Japan.
• • Follow-up period was 90 ± 72 weeks (1.7 ± 1.4 years).
• • Considered sex, age, ADLs, Fontaine stage, infection, diabetic condition, hypertension, dyslipidemia, smoking, regular hemodialysis, and serum albumin level.
• • Diabetic condition determined as presence of diabetes and glycemic control in diabetic population.
• • PTA was first-choice procedure for revascularization, not feasible for heavily calcified or diffuse occlusions.
• • Major amputation indicated when revascularization failed to relieve rest pain or control foot lesions, or when there was insufficient blood flow or uncontrollable limb infection.
• • Data presented as means and SDs for continuous variables or percentages for dichotomous variables.
• • Limb salvage and survival plotted using Kaplan-Meier method, differences assessed by log-rank test.
• • Cox proportional hazards regression model used to determine unadjusted association of each variable with outcome.
• • Diabetic patients had higher rate of major amputation (p = 0.008) but similar life prognosis (p = 0.717) compared to nondiabetic patients.
• • Presence of diabetes independently associated with major amputation (adjusted HR: 3.101, 95% CI: 1.262-7.621, p = 0.014).
• • In diabetic patients, A1C level independently associated with major amputation (adjusted HR: 1.349, 95% CI: 1.103-1.650, p = 0.004).
• • Diabetes with A1C ≥ 6.8% significantly associated with major amputation compared to nondiabetic group.
• • Diabetes with A1C ≥ 6.8%, infection, and hemodialysis independently associated with major amputation.

+ • CE is caused by Echinococcus granulosus, a widespread parasitic zoonosis.
+ • Humans acquire infection by ingesting eggs from infected dogs.
+ • Diagnosis is typically established by radiology and serology.
+ • CE can present with symptoms associated with fluid-filled cysts in various organs.
+ • Relapses can occur after treatment due to non-radical surgical procedures or spillage of parasite material.
+ • Relapse rates vary between 2 and 25%.
+ • Long-term follow-up is necessary to detect newly growing or relapsing cysts.
+ • Serology has limitations in post-operative monitoring due to long persistence of antibodies.
+ • The study examined the pattern of antigenic bands essential for CE diagnosis using immunoblotting.
+ • It also reported on the post-operative evolution of patients and the diagnostic performance of Western blot.
+ • Blood samples were collected from 50 CE patients, 40 non-CE patients, and 20 healthy controls.
+ • All CE patients received antihelminthic treatment and underwent surgical procedures.
+ • IgG reactivity from CE patients revealed multiple immunoreactive bands ranging from 18 to 239 kDa.
+ • Major immunoreactive bands in pre-operative samples were 24, 39, 46, 52, 57, 60-61, and 63 kDa.
+ • Antigenic bands of 52, 24, 39, 46, 63, and 60-61 kDa were specific for hydatid disease.
+ • The 39 kDa band reactivity decreased significantly post-operatively.
+ • Western blotting appears to be a useful method for post-surgical monitoring of CE.
+ • Antibodies against proteins of 24 and 39 kDa constitute a good marker for post-surgical monitoring.
+ • These antibodies disappear in post-operative samples of cured patients but remain as long as cysts persist.
+ • Further studies are required to analyze the behavior of these antibodies after medical treatment.
• Aim: Examine relationship between obesity parameters and serum lipid levels in obese non-diabetic patients.
• Population: 66 obese (BMI 30 kg/m²) non-diabetic patients (40 women, 26 men) aged 55.8 ± 11.6 years.
• Obesity parameters: BMI, WC, WHR, WHtR, BAI, VAI.
• Lipid levels: Total cholesterol (TC), LDL-C, HDL-C, triglycerides (TG), and lipid indices (TC/HDL-C, LDL-C/HDL-C, TG/HDL-C).
• Significant differences in WC, WHtR, BAI, BMI, TC, and LDL-C among obesity classes.
• Negative correlations between BMI, WC, WHR, VAI, and HDL-C.
• Positive correlations between WC, WHR, VAI, and TG/HDL-C ratio.
• VAI showed the strongest correlation with TG, HDL-C, and lipid indices.
• VAI's formula inclusion of HDL-C and TG levels may contribute to its strong correlation.
• One of the few studies focusing on obese patients grouped by obesity level, including morbidly obese (BMI 40 kg/m²).
• Obesity, especially abdominal obesity, is significantly associated with dyslipidemia, mainly reduced HDL-C.
• VAI may be the most valuable obesity index in obese patients with dyslipidemias.

column1: • Rapid growth in internet use worldwide, including India.
• Internet addiction labeled as a subset of behavior addiction, with various types like cyber-sexual addiction and net compulsions.
• Prevalence of internet addiction varies, with 6% among the general population and 14% among college students.
• Aimed to study the prevalence of internet addiction and its association with psychopathology in college-going students in Mumbai.
• Conducted a cross-sectional survey in three colleges, covering 987 students aged 16-18.
• Found that 74.5% were moderate users, 24.8% were possible addicts, and 0.7% were addicts.
• Males were more likely to be addicted than females.
• Addicts had poor mental, physical, and social health scores, and high anxiety, depression, and anxiety-depression scores.
• Internet addiction may be a distinct disorder or a behavioral problem secondary to another disorder, and further research is needed to determine its classification and develop interventions.

column1: • CVD is the leading cause of death in the US, accounting for 29.4% of total deaths in 2010.
• CVD cost the US $312.6 billion in healthcare spending and lost productivity in 2010.
• Aspirin therapy can reduce the risk of major cardiovascular events.
• It is recommended by the US Preventive Services Task Force for primary and secondary CVD prevention.
• **Study on Aspirin Use and Physician Recommendations**
• The study analyzed data from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) for 2011-2012.
• It focused on adults aged 40 and older who were asked about aspirin use and physician recommendations.
• Less than a third of primary prevention patients were recommended aspirin by their doctor.
• Over three-fourths of primary prevention patients were classified as low risk, but still, over a quarter were recommended aspirin.
• Among high-risk patients, fewer than half reported receiving recommendations for aspirin.
• Objective risk level was not associated with an increased risk of recommendation for aspirin in multivariate analysis.
* **Role of Mitochondria and ROS in Cellular Differentiation**

column2: + * Mitochondria produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) during oxidative metabolism, which act as signaling molecules

column3: - ROS oxidize cysteine residues on proteins, regulating signaling pathways
- Mitochondrial ROS (mROS) generation is required for various cellular signaling pathways, including those regulating tumorigenesis, immune responses, and stress adaptation

column2: + * Increased mitochondrial content and ROS levels correlate with stem cell differentiation

column3: - Mitochondrial and oxidant content is higher in differentiated cells compared to stem cells
- Low mitochondrial mass and oxidant content correlate with stem cell maintenance

column2: + * Mitochondria and mROS play key roles in promoting keratinocyte differentiation and hair growth

column3: - Conditional deletion of TFAM in epidermal keratinocytes impairs differentiation and causes perinatal mortality in mice
- mROS generation is required for activation of Notch and Wnt/β-catenin transcriptional programs that promote epidermal differentiation and hair growth

column2: + * Nucleoredoxin (NXN) is a putative target of mROS-mediated Wnt/β-catenin signaling

column3: - NXN becomes oxidized when wild-type keratinocytes are treated with Wnt-3a, but not in TFAM knockout keratinocytes
- Further studies are needed to determine how mROS regulate Notch transcriptional activity during keratinocyte differentiation

column1: * **Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) Detection in Liver Tissue**

column2: + *Established In Situ Hybridization (ISH) Technique*

column3: - Uses LNA probe and biotin-free tyramide amplification system (CSAI)
- Detects HCV-RNA in formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) liver tissues

column2: + *Validation with Humanized Liver Specimens*

column3: - Positive controls: HCV-infected chimeric mice liver samples
- Negative controls: Non-infected chimeric mice liver samples

column2: + *Application to Human Liver Biopsies*

column3: - Detected HCV-RNA in 9 out of 11 chronic hepatitis C lesions
- No detection in HBV-related lesions, fatty liver, autoimmune hepatitis, or HCC lesions

column2: + *Sensitivity and Specificity*

column3: - Comparable sensitivity to in situ RT-PCR
- Specific to HCV-infected hepatocytes, not detected in non-hepatocellular components

column2: + *Potential for Routine Diagnosis*

column3: - Simple and reliable technique for FFPE liver biopsy specimens
- May become a valuable tool for routine histopathological diagnosis of HCV infection

column2: + *Thyroid System Disruption*

column3: - Many chemicals alter thyroid system in vertebrates, with disruption of thyroid axis being an important consideration for regulation.
- OECD and EPA established guidelines using frog metamorphosis to investigate thyroid toxicity.

column2: + *Amphibian Metamorphosis Assay (AMA)*

column3: - AMA is a generalized vertebrate model based on the functions of the hypothalamic-pituitary-thyroid (HPT) axis.
- OECD and EPA adopted AMA as a guideline for testing chemicals, with thyroid gland histology being a primary endpoint.

column2: • • CS performed for medical indications is necessary for life-saving and to prevent maternal or perinatal complications.
• • Increasing rates of CS without medical indication contribute to higher global rates.
• • Debate exists regarding the appropriateness of CS performed due to maternal request or physician suggestion.
• • WHO recommends a 10-15% CS rate, but many countries exceed this range.
• • CS rate in Iran has increased six-fold over the past three decades.
• • The debate on the best practices (vaginal delivery vs. CS) to minimize postnatal morbidity continues.
• • The postpartum period is critical for women, leading to physiological, emotional, and social changes.
• • Socio-economic deficiencies and medical problems are risk factors for decreased QoL and depressive symptoms.
• • Mode of delivery and childbirth experience may have a long-term effect on self-rated health.
• • Aim: To explore the impact of delivery mode on women's postpartum physical and mental health-related QoL.
• • Methodology: Prospective study in Iran (August 2007 to October 2008) with 342 women (175 vaginal deliveries, 167 CS).
• • Follow-up assessments at 2 and 4 months postpartum using the SF-36 questionnaire.
• • Physical health QoL at 2 and 4 months after delivery was better in women with vaginal delivery.
• • Significant differences were found in physical functioning and role physical parameters at both time points.
• • Mental health QoL at 4 months after delivery and improvement from time 1 to time 2 were better in the vaginal delivery group.
• • Mental health QoL at 2 months after delivery was better in the CS group but not significant.
• • Some studies reported decreased QoL in CS delivery, while others did not find any relation.
• • A study in rural China found no significant difference in QoL between normal delivery and CS.
• • A cohort study in Iran found generally higher QoL parameters in planned CS women compared to vaginal delivery.
• • Use of a general instrument only.

column2: • • Safety Needs

column3: - Personal security, financial security, health, and well-being

column2: • • Belongingness and Love Needs
• • Esteem Needs
• • Self-Actualization Needs
• • Safety needs can block physiological needs
• • Negativity bias: faster and more fundamental than hedonic needs
• • Safety needs inhibit reaction in adults, but not in infants
• • Safety needs are the major reason for mental disorders
• • Fear - Anger - Happiness - Sadness - Calm
• • Fear and anger are due to unexpected events
• • Happiness and sadness are due to hedonic value
• • Emotional flow constitutes everyday emotions
• • Amygdala: fear and anxiety
• • LC/NE system: fight or flight, fear and anger
• • Safety circuitry: fight or flight, fear and anger emotions, conditioned learning
• • Fear and anger are due to safety needs, joy and sadness are due to physiological needs

column1: * **EETs and their role in physiological functions:**

column2: + Blood pressure regulation
+ Nociception (pain perception)
+ Adipogenesis (fat cell formation)
+ Anti-inflammatory activity
+ Organ regeneration
+ Insulin potentiation
+ Podocyte integrity (maintaining kidney function)
+ Cellular responses to bacterial infection
+ Metabolized from arachidonic acid by cytochromes P450, specifically members of the 2c and 2j families
+ Ratio of EET isomers and stereocomposition dependent on CYP P450 isoform and species/tissue-specific
+ Factors complicating EET research and therapeutic utility:

column3: - Susceptibility to aerial oxidation or auto-oxidation
- Inactivating enzymatic processes (esterification, metabolism, conjugation, etc.)
- Hydration of the epoxide by soluble epoxide hydrolase (SEH) as a major determinant of steady-state levels

column2: + Inhibition of SEH can elevate EET levels both in vitro and in vivo
+ SEH inhibition might be less efficacious than agonist replacement therapy when endogenous EET biosynthesis is compromised
+ Strategies for EET replacement therapy:

column3: - Direct administration of EETs (e.g., 14,15-EET)
- Use of EET surrogates with improved stability
- Agonist replacement therapy with compounds that mimic EET activity

column1: • Developed by major medical associations to improve healthcare quality and reduce costs
• Based on Edward Wagner's Chronic Care Model (CCM)
• PCMH aims to provide quality, coordinated, and cost-effective care, increase access, and improve practice efficiency
• Recognition by National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA) increases likelihood of reimbursement for PCMH procedures
• Practices must create written policies adhering to PCMH principles and fit their specific structure
• Transition can be incremental or all at once, with NCQA recognition tiers based on performance elements satisfied
• Resistance due to lack of training, misaligned incentives, underreimbursement, and time-consuming procedures
• Emphasize time-saving benefits and patient care improvements
• Significant changes in staff roles and responsibilities
• Patient education and engagement crucial for success
• Care coordinators improve patient follow-ups and education
• Population management requires additional space and resources
• EMR facilitates care coordination and disease management
• Challenges in creating and implementing practice-specific EMR templates
• Resource constraints may limit PCMH implementation
• Shared coordinators and optimized clinical space can help smaller practices transition

column2: • Increased training in CPR and deployment of portable defibrillators led to incremental improvements in survival from cardiac arrest.
• Most patients still did not survive or had severe neurological damage.
• Survival rate of cardiac arrest outside the hospital remained around 78%.
• About one-quarter of patients regained pulses after CPR, and one-third of those survived hospitalization.
• Severe brain damage after CPR stimulated research into the pathophysiology and treatments for global brain ischemia.
• Mild hypothermia therapy was proposed to protect the brain.
• Many animal experiments showed that hypothermia increased survival rates and improved neurological function.
• It reduced metabolic rate and expression of pro-apoptosis proteins.
• Some clinical trials proved the effectiveness of hypothermia in improving patient outcomes.
• However, recent trials showed mixed results, leading to a meta-analysis.
• A meta-analysis was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of mild hypothermia on cardiac arrest patients.
• Studies were included if they were randomized controlled trials, involved adult patients successfully resuscitated from cardiac arrest, and used therapeutic mild hypothermia.
• No significant difference in survival rate at hospital discharge between treatment and control groups.
• Significant difference in survival rate after 6 months, favoring the hypothermia group.
• No significant difference in neurological function at hospital discharge between groups.
• Significant difference in neurological function after 6 months, favoring the hypothermia group.
• No influence of mild hypothermia on the incidence of rearrest or other adverse events.
• Sensitivity analysis showed consistent results even after removing high-risk studies.
• Limitations included small trial numbers, low precision of outcome parameters, and clinical and methodological heterogeneity.
• Mild hypothermia did not improve survival rate or neurological function at hospital discharge.
• It did improve prognosis of patients after 6 months and did not increase adverse events.
+ *Prevalence and Diagnosis*

column3: - Approximately 40% of marital infertility is due to a male factor, with varicocele being one of the most common causes.
- Varicocele is characterized by persistent enlargement and elongation of the pampiniform plexus, venous convolution, and sinus formation with transient or permanent backflow.
- Diagnosis involves physical examination (inspection and palpation) and confirmation with accessory ultrasound, preferably Doppler examination.

column2: + *Etiopathogenesis and Effects on Testis*

column3: - The exact cause of varicocele is unclear, but it is believed to be due to increased hydrostatic pressure within the testicular vein, leading to venous stasis and compromised testicular oxygen concentration.
- Retrograde flow of renal metabolites and adrenal hormones to the testis may also occur due to blood turbulence in the vicinity of the opening of the testicular vein.
- Varicocele can lead to atrophic changes within convoluted tubules, increased scrotal temperature, tissue hypoxia, and testicular growth arrest in children and adolescents.

column2: + *Surgical Repair*

column3: - Laparoscopic repair is the preferred method, involving transperitoneal approach with division of the testicular vein only.
- The study reported a significant increase in hypotrophic testicular volume in 83.8% of subjects after surgery.

column2: + *Semen Parameters and Hormonal Levels*

column3: - Postoperative semen analysis revealed normozoospermia in 85.2% of patients, with the remaining 14.7% having various spermatogenesis abnormalities.

- Normal levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), luteinizing hormone (LH), and testosterone (T) were found in normozoospermic men, while those with spermatogenesis abnormalities showed FSH and LH elevation with low T levels.

column2: + *Recurrence and Complications*

column3: - Varicocele recurrence was observed in 2.9% of patients, and complications developed in 8.8% of patients, including hydrocele testis and epididymitis.
- Overall convalescence was 7 to 12 days, with a mean of 8.2 days.

+ RA is a progressive autoimmune disease characterized by chronic inflammation, degradation of articular cartilage, and subchondral bone.
+ SAA is a highly conserved acute-phase protein released in response to inflammation or infection, and its production is stimulated by proinflammatory cytokines.
+ SAA is not only an acute-phase protein but also an apolipoprotein relevant in cholesterol metabolism.

+ High SAA levels can contribute up to 80% of HDL apolipoprotein composition, impairing the protective function of HDL and increasing LDL oxidation, which may be associated with cardiovascular (CV) disease and atherogenesis.

+ SAA is the precursor of amyloid A protein, a fibrillar, insoluble product deposited in major organs, which carries a risk of organ failure and premature death in the course of secondary amyloidosis.

+ The aim of the study was to assess the concentration of SAA in RA patients with different disease activity, with reference to other inflammatory, metabolic parameters, as well as CV and renal disease risk factors.

+ The study found that serum SAA concentration was high above normal in the vast majority of RA patients, and elevated SAA levels were found not only in patients with high disease activity but also in those with low or moderate disease activity.

column2: + Evaluate apical debris extrusion after using Protaper Universal RFS and different finishing files for removing residual root canal fillings.
+ No significant differences in debris extrusion among Protaper Next (PTN), WaveOne (WO), and Self-Adjusting File (SAF).
+ 80 teeth divided into four groups for retreatment.
+ Group 1: RFS only (control).
+ Group 2: RFS + PTN.
+ Group 3: RFS + WO.
+ Group 4: RFS + SAF.
+ RFS: D1, D2, D3 at 2-Ncm torque and 500-rpm speed.
+ PTN: X2, X3, X4 at 300 rpm and 3-Ncm torque.
+ WO: Large file in preprogrammed mode.
+ SAF: 2.0 mm with continuous irrigation and Endosolv R.
+ Apical debris collected and dried.
+ Weight measurements taken for each collection assembly.
+ One-way ANOVA and post hoc test used.
+ Percentage of debris extruded compared to control group.
+ WO extruded significantly more debris than PTN and SAF (p < 0.01).
+ SAF extruded the least debris among experimental groups (p < 0.01).
+ WO: 27% increase, PTN: 19% increase, SAF: 12% increase compared to control.
+ All retreatment systems caused apical debris extrusion.
+ SAF instrumentation after RFS resulted in less extrusion than PTN and WO.
+ None declared.

column2: • • Have enhanced understanding of higher-order genome folding
• • Revealed dynamic folding of chromatin regulates gene expression and DNA replication
• • Identified chromosome territories, genomic compartments, and topologically associating domains (TADs)
• • TADs are stable units with specific long-range looping interactions
• • Range from 100 kb to 1 Mb in size
• • Exhibit higher frequency of physical contacts between genes and regulatory regions
• • Boundaries serve as barriers to long- and short-range DNA interactions
• • Strength of boundaries varies, affecting inter-TAD interactions
• • Regulates expression of genes related to extracellular matrix and lipid synthesis
• • Affects expression of long non-coding RNAs involved in genome organization
• • Binds primarily at genic regions, including super-enhancers
• • Contributes to the integrity and strength of TAD boundaries
• • Reduces nucleosome occupancy at CTCF-bound regions
• • Alters nucleosome occupancy and reduces boundary strength
• • May perturb binding of CTCF and topoisomerases
• • Affects chromatin structure and stiffness at TAD boundaries
• • Interplay and functional cooperativity in TAD organization
• • Brg1 recruits topoisomerases to chromatin via its ATPase activity
• • Evidence from bacteria and yeast supports role of topoisomerases in genome organization
• • Perturbations in recruitment of CTCF and topoisomerases may affect TAD integrity
• • Strong link between chromatin remodeling enzymes and genome organization
• • Other complexes may play similar roles to Brg1 in TAD formation and function
• • Continued examination of factors at TAD boundaries will provide insights into chromatin folding and genome organization

column2: • • Intracellular pathogens have evolved to coexist with host defense mechanisms.
• • Studying host response in vivo is challenging due to pathogen-specific responses and general inflammatory responses.
• • Complement cascade, coagulation pathway, and acute phase response are activated within minutes of infection.
• • Leishmania infects various myeloid cells, with a predilection for resident tissue macrophages.
• • In vivo response of liver macrophages to Leishmania infection was studied.
• • Infected and uninfected cells exposed to inflammatory signals were independently studied.
• • Infected and inflamed Kupffer cells (KCs) showed distinct transcriptomic responses.
• • Commonly regulated genes included inflammatory response and cytokine-cytokine receptor interaction.
• • Unique genes in inflamed cells were enriched in lipid metabolism and small-molecule biochemistry pathway.
• • Rxra-centered transcriptomic pathway was aberrantly maintained in infected KCs.
• • Pharmacological manipulation of Rxr activity perturbed the transcriptomic network and enhanced leishmanicidal activity.
• • Rxr perturbation reduced parasite burden in the liver and spleen.
• • The use of cells exposed to inflammation is a powerful method for discovering pathogen-regulated gene pathways.
• • The approach revealed important host response pathways and impacted parasite survival in vivo.
• • Targeting nuclear receptors, such as Rxr, for therapy is a promising approach for leishmaniasis.

+ Major depression is a leading cause of disability and burden of disease, projected to be second by 2020.
+ TRD affects up to 40% of patients and can lead to suicide, with about 850,000 deaths annually.
+ TRD lacks a universal definition, but poor response to two adequate trials of different antidepressant classes is commonly used.
+ Researchers categorize TRD into stages based on antidepressant trials and augmentation strategies.
+ Staging helps understand TRD patients and plan interventions for enhancing response, remission, and quality of life.
+ NTs target specific brain circuits, have limited side effects, and minimal drug interactions.

+ Examples include electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS), vagus nerve stimulation (VNS), deep brain stimulation (DBS), and transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS).
+ ECT is effective in TRD but causes transient confusion, amnesia, and has a high relapse rate.
+ Ketamine as an anesthetic prior to ECT may enhance its antidepressant effect.
+ Combination therapies with ECT and pharmacotherapy may be beneficial.
+ rTMS is safer and more selective than ECT, with fewer side effects.
+ High-frequency rapid (HFR) rTMS is preferred over low-frequency slow (LFS) rTMS.
+ Sequential bilateral rTMS and unilateral rTMS are efficacious in TRD.
+ VNS targets specific brain networks and has shown sustained benefit in TRD patients.
+ Long-term VNS is associated with sustained benefit and good functional status.
+ VNS has no adverse neuropsychological effects and is cost-effective compared to ECT.
+ Larger, collaborative, multisite studies are needed to establish the efficacy, safety, and cost-effectiveness of NTs in TRD.
+ More specific subpopulations and endophenotypes should be targeted in treatment trials.
+ Direct comparisons with antidepressant drugs are needed.
+ Optimal parameters for NTs should be defined using adaptive designs and collaborative networks.

column1: * **History and Evolution of Betel Nut and Tobacco Use in India**

column2: + *Traditional Practice and Cultural Acceptance*

column3: - Chewing of betel nut was a common practice in India for centuries
- It was considered innocuous and had socio-cultural acceptance

column2: + *Introduction of Tobacco*

column3: - Tobacco was introduced by European settlers four centuries ago
- It was mixed with betel quid and culturally accepted

column2: + *Association with Oral Cancer*

column3: - The association of betel quid with oral cancer was noted over a century ago
- Tobacco in the quid was the major culprit, but areca nut was initially thought to play a more important role

column2: + *Increase in Incidence and Prevalence*

column3: - The incidence of oral cancer has increased in recent years
- This is due to the increasing use of gutkha and pan masala, which contain tobacco and areca nut

column2: + *Patient Demographics*

column3: - 63 patients (38 males and 25 females) were included in the study
- The youngest patient was 47 years old and the oldest was 73

column2: + *Findings and Treatment*

column3: - Most cases were in advanced stages (TNM staging)
- All patients were managed according to the oral cancer management protocol

column2: + *Chemical Composition and Effects*

column3: - Betel nut contains alkaloids like arecoline, arecaidine, guvacine, and guvacoline
- These alkaloids are cholinergic agonists and affect the nervous system via acetylcholine

column2: + *Health Impacts*

column3: - Prolonged use of betel nut causes facial and systemic features, staining and attrition of teeth, and periodontitis
- It is also associated with oral cancer, oral precancerous lesions, hepatocarcinoma, diabetes mellitus, and cardiovascular diseases

column2: + *Regulations and Bans*

column3: - A ban on betel nut, betel quid, and tobacco in any form is necessary to eradicate the menace of morbidity
- A permanent ban on gutkha and panmasala is necessary as they are well-established oral cancer-causing",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

- Risk of severe postoperative infections and adverse effects

column2: + *Postoperative Bleeding:*

column3: - Common in cardiac surgery
- Factors contributing to excessive bleeding

column2: + *Transfusion Guidelines:*

column3: - Not dictated by a single hemoglobin level
- Based on patient's risk of developing complications of inadequate oxygenation

column2: + *Neurogenesis in Adult Mammals*

column3: - *Historical Beliefs*

column4: - Neurons and non-neuronal cells in the nervous system were believed to be incapable of active division and transformation.
- Lack of specific markers for progenitor stem cells in the nervous system niche.

column3: - *Demonstration of Neurogenesis*

column4: - Joseph Altman's work in 1962 and 1963 showed neurogenesis in the cerebral cortex and dentate gyrus of the hippocampus.
- Later studies showed neurogenesis in the subgranular zone, subventricular zone, and cerebellum during adulthood.

column2: + *Olfactory System Neurogenesis*

column3: - Neurogenesis occurs in the olfactory bulbs and olfactory mucosa.
- This research focuses on a population of stem cells in the olfactory epithelium.

column2: + *Olfactory Epithelial-Mesenchymal Stem Cells*

column3: - Previous isolation methods using collagenase Ia and immunoadhesion resulted in impure cultures.
- This research standardizes chemical methods for pure isolation of these stem cells.

column2: + *Isolation and Characterization*

column3: - GBCs were isolated using FACS with gbc-iii antibody, achieving 99% purity.
- Immunostaining with neural progenitor cell markers (NCAM, Nestin, Sox-2, CD-29, CD-54, CD-73) confirmed their neural progenitor nature.

column2: + *Electrophysiological Characterization*

column3: - Patch-clamping studies showed the unexcitable nature of GBCs, with no voltage-gated Na+ channels and only leaky K+ channels present.

column2: + *Future Research Directions*

column3: - Isolation of GBCs using MACS for comparison with FACS and improved purity.
- Electrophysiological studies to understand ion channels and drug interactions.
- Animal studies to repair spinal cord injuries and other nervous system disorders using GBCs.

column1: * **Central Nervous System (CNS) Immune Privilege and Microglia:**

column2: + *Historical View:*

column3: - CNS was considered a site of immune privilege.
- Microglia's role in innate immunity was not well understood.

column2: + *Current Understanding:*

column3: - Microglia play a pivotal role in innate immunity within the CNS.
- Glymphatic system enables communication between brain parenchyma and cervical lymph nodes.
- CNS immune system is more constitutively active than previously thought.

column2: + *Origin:*

column3: - Microglia are derived from erythromyeloid progenitors in the yolk sac.
- These progenitors express the chemokine receptor CX3CR1.

column2: + *Development:*

column3: - Mouse microglia develop from primitive c-kit erythromyeloid precursors present in the yolk sac at E7.5-E8.0.
- Microglial maturation involves reduction in CD31 expression and upregulation of F4/80 and MCSF-R.
- Microglia invade the developing brain at E9.5 and are maintained through cellular division or expansion of progenitors.

column2: + *Immune Surveillance and Inflammation:*

column3: - Microglia are involved in immune surveillance and initiate inflammatory responses when necessary.
- They phagocytose pathogens, apoptotic neurons, and tissue debris.
- Microglia-derived TNF can exert neuroprotective or neurodestructive actions.

column2: + *Synaptic Refinement and Angiogenesis:*

column3: - Microglia play a role in synaptic refinement and angiogenesis.
- They express CR3, required for synaptic pruning, and secrete BDNF for synapse formation.
- Genetic inhibition of microglia results in derangement of synapse formation and elimination of dendritic spines.

column2: + *CSD Characteristics:*

column3: - CSD is a wave of rapid, near-complete depolarization of neurons and astrocytes followed by electrical suppression.
- It is accompanied by secondary changes in cerebral blood flow.

column2: + *Microglia and CSD:*

column3: - Microglia express voltage-sensitive ion channels and sense electrical activity pertaining to CSD.
- CSD can initiate inflammatory activation of microglia, leading to ROS production, IL-1",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

column1: * **Transposable Elements (TEs) and Their Role in Evolution**

column2: + *Historical Viewpoint*

column3: - Initially considered as ""junk DNA"" and selfish elements
- Capable of moving and inserting into new locations within genomes
- Two main categories: retroelements and DNA transposons

column2: * **Retroelements**

column3: - Use reverse transcription to generate new copies
- Distinction made between LTR retrotransposons and non-LTR retrotransposons
- Retroviruses and syncytins are examples of domesticated retroelements

column2: * **DNA Transposons**

column3: - Excise from their original insertion site and reintegrate into a new location
- Transposition catalyzed by an enzyme called transposase
- Examples of domesticated DNA transposons include integrases, transposases, and zinc finger proteins

column1: • Affect increasing number of people (45 million worldwide, expected to reach 76 million in 2030)
• High societal costs and loss in life expectancy and quality of life
• Caused by aggregation of misfolded or incorrectly processed polypeptides
• Spread from one cell to another through template-driven misfolding
• Examples: Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, Huntington's, and Creutzfeldt-Jakob diseases
• Molecular chaperones oppose protein misfolding, unfolding, and aggregation
• Heat shock response corrects misfolding and unfolding
• Ubiquitin proteasome system and autophagy clear misfolded proteins
• Can cause loss of function and gain of toxic function
• Spread and transmit in a prion-like manner
• Fibrillar assemblies exhibit seeding capacity and toxicity
• Oligomers may also be toxic, but their role is debated
• Brain extracts containing aggregates induce lesions characteristic of various diseases
• Aggregates move between cells and tissues
• Aggregates can be taken up and internalized by cells
• Can be considered infectious, in accordance with modified Koch's postulates
• Different strains of prion protein (PrP) and alpha-synuclein (α-syn) exist
• Distinct strains have different properties, tropism, and seeding propensity
• Targeting disease-associated protein assemblies propagation and seeding capacities
• Small molecules, neurotrophic factors, and immunotherapy explored
• Interfering with α-syn assemblies docking to cells as a promising strategy

column2: • HCV prevalence and treatment response in AA

column3: - AA are twice as likely to be infected with HCV compared to non-Hispanic Caucasians
- AA have historically had lower response rates to interferon (IFN)-based therapies

column2: • HCV-related morbidity and mortality in AA

column3: - AA are at risk for developing advanced liver disease, despite slower fibrosis progression compared to Caucasians
- More specific information is needed to understand liver disease progression in AA, especially after viral clearance

column2: • Sustained Viral Response (SVR) and improved outcomes

column3: - Patients who achieve SVR have better outcomes, including reduced cirrhosis, HCC development, and all-cause mortality
- AA are at lower risk for liver events compared to Caucasians after achieving SVR

column2: • IFN-based therapies and HCC development in AA

column3: - AA males are more likely to develop HCC than females, but patients achieving SVR or end-of-treatment response (ETR) with subsequent relapse did not develop HCC regardless of gender
- Time to HCC development was not significantly different between genders

column2: • First clinical visit parameters and HCC risk

column3: - No reliable predictors of HCC development on an individual basis, including serum assays and fibrosis assays
- Cirrhosis at the first visit was not predictive of HCC development in AA

column2: • Multivariate analysis and fibrosis as a predictor

column3: - Only fibrosis, as defined by biopsy at the first visit, was moderately predictive of HCC development in AA
- Time to HCC was not related to cirrhosis status at the first visit

column2: • Study design and population

column3: - Prospective study with an average follow-up of 8 years, focusing on AA patients with HCV genotype 1
- Insufficient numbers of Caucasians for statistical analysis

column2: • HCC surveillance and therapy goals

column3: - Elimination of the virus remains the optimal goal of therapy, as predicting HCC development in AA remains challenging
- Surveillance in patients with significant fibrosis, rather than just cirrhosis, is warranted

column1: • Stroke is the second leading cause of death globally.
- Accounts for nearly 5.7 million deaths annually.
- 87% of stroke deaths occur in low- and middle-income nations.
• Genetic influences play a significant role in ischemic stroke pathogenesis.
- Polygenic, with multiple genes exerting small influences on phenotype.
• βARs are G-protein coupled receptors involved in neurohormone signaling.
- Uncoupling from adenylyl cyclase, internalization, and phosphorylation contribute to loss of receptor activity.
• Cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) modulates vascular function and inflammation, contributing to atherosclerosis.
- cAMP is a potential target for atherosclerosis prevention and treatment.
• Major non-synonymous SNPs of 2AR (Arg16Gly and Gln27Glu) influence receptor function.
- Arg16Gly variant exhibits enhanced agonist-mediated receptor down-regulation.
- Gln27Glu variant shows resistance to down-regulation.
- No significant association between Arg16Gly polymorphism and ischemic stroke.
- Significant association between Gln27Glu polymorphism and ischemic stroke under recessive, dominant, and allelic models.
- Lack of haplotype analysis and gene-gene/environment interactions.
- Potential selection bias and deviation from HWE equilibrium.
- Well-designed, larger prospective cohort studies to validate findings.
- Investigation of underlying molecular causal pathways for ischemic stroke susceptibility.
* **Methadone's Impact on Cognition and Calcium Homeostasis**

column2: + *Impairs Cognitive Abilities*

column3: - Psychomotor performance
- Information processing
- Attention, problem-solving, memory, decision-making, reaction time

column2: + *Alters Calcium Homeostasis*

column3: - Increases cytosolic free calcium concentration ([Ca]cyt)
- Induces delayed calcium deregulation (DCD)
- May lead to cell death via mitochondrial permeability transition pore (MPTP)

column1: * **Mechanisms of Methadone-Induced Calcium Dysregulation in SH-SY5Y Cells**

column2: + *Mitochondria-Dependent*

column3: - Mitochondrial calcium overload
- Mitochondrial permeability transition pore (MPTP) formation
- Mitochondrial fragmentation and damage

column2: + *Independent of Plasma Membrane Calcium Channels and Opioid Receptors*

column3: - Extracellular calcium entry not involved
- Voltage-dependent calcium channels not involved
- Opioid receptors not involved

column1: * **Methadone's Effect on Mitochondrial Function and Morphology**

column2: + *Impairs Mitochondrial Calcium Uptake*

column3: - Dependent on respiratory substrates
- Reduces uncoupling capacity

column2: + *Induces Mitochondrial Morphological Changes*

column3: - Mitochondrial fragmentation
- Mitochondrial swelling (in neurodegenerative diseases)
- Mitochondrial damage and cell death

column2: + **Meta-Analysis Findings**

column3: - Strong association with reduced risks of breast, ovarian, and fallopian tube cancers
- Summary risk reduction estimates: 80% for ovarian/fallopian tube cancer, 50% for breast cancer
- Consistent findings across studies, confirming utility of RRSO in this population

column2: + **Study Limitations and Unanswered Questions**

column3: - Limited data on birth cohort, timing of surgery, and other influencing factors
- Few estimates for BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutation carriers separately
- Need for larger studies to evaluate tumor markers and optimal age for RRSO
- Complex relationship between RRSO and hormone replacement therapy (HRT)

column1: * **Clinical Recommendations and Other Risk Reduction Strategies**

column2: + **RRSO as Standard of Care**

column3: - Substantial reduction in breast and ovarian cancer risks
- Improved overall survival in the short term

column2: + **Other Risk Reduction Options**

column3: - Risk-reducing mastectomy for breast cancer risk reduction
- Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for early detection of breast cancer
- Need for additional cancer risk reduction and screening strategies

column1: * **Oral Lichen Planus (OLP) and the IL-23/IL-17 Axis**

column2: + **Prevalence and Characteristics**

column3: - Chronic inflammatory disease affecting oral mucosa
- Prevalence of about 1-2% of the population
- Rarely undergoes self-remission and may have malignant potential

column2: + **Etiology and Pathogenesis**

column3: - Immune dysregulation, especially T-cell-mediated immune response
- Aberrant production of various inflammatory molecules

column2: + **IL-23/IL-17 Axis in OLP**

column3: - Newly discovered proinflammatory signaling pathway
- IL-23 and IL-17 are pivotal cytokines in this axis
- IL-23 induces Th17 cells to produce IL-17, which activates various cells to produce inflammatory molecules

column2: + **Expression of IL-23/IL-17 in OLP**

column3: - Overexpression of IL-23 and IL-17 in OLP lesions
- IL-23 and IL-17 expressions positively correlated in reticular OLP lesions
- IL-23 upregulation associated with increased IL-17 levels in early-stage OLP

column2: + **IL-23 and IL-17 Production in OLP**

column3: - IL-23 stimulates CD4+T cells (Th17) to produce IL-17 in OLP patients
- IL-17 selectively regulates the expressions of some inflammatory mediators in oral keratinocytes

column2: + **Potential Role of IL-23/IL-17 Axis in OLP**

column3: - Novel model of interaction between T cells and keratinocytes in OLP pathogenesis
- IL-23/IL-17 axis may represent a new signaling pathway in the crosstalk between keratinocytes and CD4+T cells

column2: + **Future Perspectives**

column3: - Further explorations on the intrinsic mechanisms and interaction with other signaling pathways
- Potential therapeutic target for the prevention and management of OLP

column2: + *Size- and Density-Based Approaches*

column3: - *Microfluidic Devices*

column4: * Force fluid through channels of varied size
* Ensure laminar flow for efficient separation

column3: - *Cell Sieves*

column4: * Use arrays of parallel channels of varied width
* Trap larger cells while allowing smaller cells to pass

column2: + *Affinity-Based Approaches*

column3: - *Fluorescence-Activated Cell Sorting (FACS)*

column4: * Use fluorescent labels and laser beams to sort cells

column3: - *Magnetic Separation*

column4: * Use magnetic beads and external magnetic fields to separate cells
* Can be miniaturized for small sample volumes

column3: - *Adhesion-Based Separation*

column4: * Use antibodies immobilized on surfaces to bind cells
* Can separate cells with the same size and/or density

column3: - *Electrophoretic Separation*

column4: * Use dielectrophoresis (DEP) to trap and sort cells based on their response to electric fields
* Allows for dynamic probing and sorting of cells

column2: + *Clinical Diagnostics*

column3: - *Point-of-care diagnostics*

column4: * Microfluidic separation systems can be easily incorporated with downstream analysis devices
* Offer potential for rapid, accurate, and cost-effective clinical diagnostics

column2: + *Drug Discovery and Chemical/Biological Agent Detection*

column3: - *High-throughput screening*

column4: * Microfluidic separation systems can be operated in a massively parallel fashion
* Enable rapid and efficient screening of large numbers of compounds or samples

column2: + *Economic Production and Ease of Operation*

column3: - *Shift from proof-of-concept prototypes to economically viable devices*

column4: * Focus on reducing costs and improving ease of use for real-world applications

column3: - *Integration with other technologies*

column4: * Combine separation systems with other technologies, such as single-cell lysis or proteomic/genomic analysis
* Enable comprehensive analysis of separated cell populations

column2: + *Caudate-to-Right Lobe Ratio (C/Rl)*

column3: - High specificity and accuracy in diagnosing cirrhosis
- Correlated with hepatic functional reserve
- Time-consuming measurement, rarely used in daily clinical work

column2: + *Expanded Gallbladder Fossa (EGF) and Right Posterior Notch (RPN)*

column3: - Simple qualitative visual signs of cirrhosis
- High specificity and positive predictive value
- Low sensitivity, but useful in clinical practice

column2: • Prospective longitudinal study evaluating optic nerve structure and visual function in glaucoma
• Conducted at the Hamilton Glaucoma Center, University of California, San Diego
• Included 462 eyes of 305 glaucoma patients and 62 eyes of 49 healthy controls
• Comprehensive ophthalmologic examinations, including SD-OCT and SAP tests
• Exclusion criteria: ocular or systemic diseases affecting the optic nerve or visual field
• Progression detection based on statistically significant slopes and rates of change slower than the fifth percentile cutoff from healthy eyes
• Logistic regression model to evaluate the relative odds of progressing by SD-OCT vs. SAP
• SD-OCT was more likely to detect progression in eyes with less severe disease and fewer visits
• SAP was more likely to detect progression in eyes with more severe disease and more visits
• Interaction between baseline disease severity and number of visits influenced the relative odds of detecting progression by SD-OCT vs. SAP

column1: * **Challenges in Healthcare Industry and Research Funding:**

column2: + *Promise of new technologies and innovations:*

column3: - Improve access, cost, and quality of care (iron triangle)

column2: + *Research funding challenges:*

column3: - Competition for less funding
- Budget cuts, sequestration, and inflationary losses
- Fewer grants and discoveries, talented scientists leaving

column2: + *Between academic research and commercialization:*

column3: - Non-economic investments and lack of commercialization pathway
- Market risk outweighing technical risk
- Academic investigators not prepared for commercial issues

column2: + *Emerging option for academic investigators:*

column3: - Balance project advancement and skill-building
- Examples: I-Corps, Coulter Foundation C3i, NIH Centers for Accelerated Innovations (NCAs)

column2: + *Three centers accelerating innovations:*

column3: - University of California, Boston (B-BIC), Cleveland (NCAC)

column2: + *Programs tailored to healthcare challenges:*

column3: - CIMIT (healthtech innovations)
- NCAC-CC (therapeutics)

column2: + *Get out of the lab and talk to stakeholders:*

column3: - Develop, test, and validate business hypotheses

column2: + *Flipped classroom structure:*

column3: - Offline assignments, interactive sessions, robust feedback

column2: + *Duration and pivots:*

column3: - At least 8-10 weeks, potential for one pivot

column2: + *Unique healthcare challenges:*

column3: - Buying dynamics, reimbursement complexity, regulatory pathway
- Culture, funding requirements

column2: + *Team composition:*

column3: - Clinical, technical, and business perspectives
- Entrepreneurial lead coordinates team efforts

column2: + *Executive faculty:*

column3: - Healthcare industry experts, consistent feedback and guidance
- Diversity of backgrounds, synthesized feedback to teams

column2: + *Integral part of an ecosystem or program:*

column3: - Early application of HCP benefits, phase 0 award
- Focus resources on high-likelihood projects and milestones

column1: • Bladder cancer is the second most common cancer in the urogenital tract.
• Smoking is a significant risk factor, with about 85% of cases limited to the bladder at diagnosis, and 15% having expanded beyond it.
• Aim: To assess the reliability of subjects' smoking history and compliance with smoking cessation recommendations.
• Method: Questionnaire and cotinine (a marker of exposure) measurement in urine.
• 35 (36%) had cotinine levels indicating active smoking.
• 4 (4%) had levels equivalent to passive smoking.
• 57 (59%) had no cotinine in their urine.

column2: + **Prevalence**

column3: - 8.4% among pregnant women in second trimester
- Higher among parous women (9.8%) than nulliparous (7.8%)

column2: + **Risk Factors**

column3: - Previous obstetric anal sphincter injury (OASIS) among parous women

column4: * Strongest risk factor for anal incontinence (AI)
* Threefold increased risk compared to women without OASIS

column3: - Low socioeconomic status (low income, low education) among nulliparous women

column4: * Significant risk factor for AI in multivariate analysis
* May indicate lower health status and increased morbidity

column2: + **Population**

column3: - Unselected female population across parity groups in second trimester of pregnancy
- 2846 women participated, response rate of 45%

column2: + **Data Collection**

column3: - Self-reported questionnaire on AI, urinary incontinence, general health, drug use, and worries
- Demographic data, obstetrical history, educational level, household income, and country of origin
- Anal incontinence identified by self-reported leakage of gas, loose or solid stools, fecal urgency, use of pads or plugs, and alteration of lifestyle

column2: + Aim: Compare hemodynamic effects of spinal anesthesia in normotensive and hypertensive patients.
+ Design: Randomized controlled study with 60 patients (30 normotensive, 30 hypertensive).
+ Patients: Age 18-65, ASA I-II, scheduled for lower abdomen, lower limbs, or perineum surgeries.
+ Anesthesia: Hyperbaric bupivacaine (3.5 ml of 0.5%) via lumbar puncture at L3-4 intervertebral space.
+ Measurements: Blood pressure (systolic, diastolic, mean), heart rate at baseline, after fluid loading, and every 1-10 minutes post-anesthesia for 60 minutes.
+ Management: Intravenous ephedrine (5 mg) for hypotension (MBP decrease >30% from baseline), atropine (0.5 mg) for bradycardia (HR <50 bpm).
+ No significant difference in hypotension incidence between groups (6/30 vs. 1/30).
+ Hypertensive patients had higher SBP, DBP, and MBP at all measurement times.
+ No significant difference in heart rate changes between groups.
+ Limitation: Lack of measurement of basal sympathetic activities.
+ Interpretation: No significant difference in hypotension incidence, but higher blood pressure in hypertensive patients due to higher basal blood pressure.
+ Aim: Determine Dolotest's usefulness as a depression screening tool in primary care.
+ Method: Diagnostic study among adult primary care patients in Denmark (Oct 2008 - Dec 2008).
+ Participants: 715 patients (response rate: 68.5%).
+ Tools: Dolotest (pain and HRQoL assessment) and Major Depression Inventory (MDI).
+ Prevalence of depression: 16.1% (12.8% in men, 18.1% in women).
+ Higher depression prevalence in pain patients (26.8%) compared to others (10.5%).
+ Dolotest domain 'low spirits' cut-off score of 65 showed high sensitivity (78%) and specificity (95%) for detecting depression.
+ Patients with depression had higher pain scores and reduced HRQoL.
+ Dolotest profiles and scores provide an easy-to-use screening tool in clinical settings.
+ Facilitates awareness and communication about depression and pain coexistence.
+ Identifies patients needing individualized treatment for both pain and depression.
+ Coexisting pain and depression increase risk of reduced function, opioid misuse, and healthcare costs.
+ Treating both conditions is crucial for optimal health-related quality of life.
+ Healthcare providers should be aware of pain symptoms in depressed patients and vice versa.
+ • HPV seroprevalence in Nigeria is high, with a global prevalence of 11.7% and regional variations.

column3: - • Africa has the highest prevalence (21.1%), with sub-Saharan Africa topping the list (24%).
- • Nigeria has a high HPV prevalence in all female age groups, with women aged 15-23 years having the highest rates.

column2: + • HPV infection is strongly associated with sexual behavior, with increasing number of sexual partners and early sexual debut increasing the prevalence.

column3: - • HPV infection can lead to cervical cancer, with persistent infection with high-risk HPV types being a major risk factor.

column2: + • HPV vaccination and cervical cancer screening programs are recommended to prevent and detect HPV-related diseases.

column3: - • Two prophylactic vaccines, Gardasil and Cervarix, are available for the prevention of genital HPV infection.
- • Improving knowledge of HPV and its vaccines, and screening women for anti-HPV and detecting genotypes, are crucial for prevention and early detection of cervical cancer.

column2: • • Medical knowledge has expanded rapidly over the past fifty years.
• • The number of scientific papers published has doubled over 10 years.
• • There's a gap between research and clinical practice.
• • Many patients don't receive care based on best scientific evidence.
• • EBM integrates best evidence with clinical experience and patient preferences.
• • It aims to improve clinical services and patient outcomes.
• • Lack of awareness and skills in using evidence.
• • Insufficient incentives for evidence-based practice.
• • Aims to generate, store, use, share, and monitor best evidence.
• • Consists of three subsystems: National System of Clinical Knowledge Management, National Evidence-Based Practice System, and Integrated National Network of Clinical Effectiveness.
• • Provides best evidence for evidence-based decision making.
• • Produces knowledge products like clinical guidelines and systematic reviews.
• • Facilitates and guarantees usage of clinical policies or knowledge products.
• • Classifies care providers and service provider centers based on evidence-based performance.
• • Ensures quality healthcare and clinical effectiveness.
• • Imposes macro interventions to promote evidence-based practice.
• • Requires a system with micro and macro strategies.
• • Needs cooperation of various stakeholders.

column1: • • Negative single-stranded RNA virus of the Paramyxoviridae family
• • Causes respiratory tract infections, especially in infants, seniors, and immunocompromised individuals
• • Has two main genetic lineages (A and B) with A2 exhibiting the greatest diversity
• • Approximately 13 kb in length with gene composition n-p-m-f-m2-1/m2-2-sh-g-l
• • Similar genomic organization to Human Respiratory Syncytial Virus (hRSV) but lacks 2 nonstructural genes (NS1 and NS2)
• • Shows synonymous codon usage bias, with preferred codons ending in A/U and none ending in G/C
• • Nucleotide composition, particularly A/U content, is the main force affecting codon usage bias
• • Mutation pressure, rather than natural selection, is the primary determinant of codon usage bias in hMPV
• • Phylogenetic differences and host factors also play roles in shaping codon usage bias, potentially influencing virulence and persistent infection

column2: + **Protsweep**

column3: - Functional characterization of unknown proteins using similarity searches
- Classifies proteins into categories: identical, homolog, similar, weakly similar, and putative
- Combines annotation from SwissProt and Ensembl

column2: + **Domainsweep**

column3: - Identifies domain architecture within a protein sequence
- Uses various database search methods and models
- Groups hits based on InterPro family, motif order, and domain consistency

column2: + **2Dsweep**

column3: - Identifies structural domains and elements in proteins
- Uses multiple structure prediction programs and DSSP annotation
- Reports on various features like secondary structure, transmembrane regions, and cleavage sites

column2: + Implemented using the w3h task framework
+ Uses public databases installed under the Sequence Retrieval System (SRS) at DKFZ
+ Automatically updated whenever new releases become available
+ Incorporates new algorithms, methodologies, and databases as they become available
+ Functionality continually updated and extended based on user requests and suggestions
+ Actively used in protein analysis and annotation by core users like Lifedb
+ Current developments include filtering strategies, confidence levels, and directed text mining
+ Aim: Investigate BH4 status, serotonergic and dopaminergic neurotransmission, and NO production in delirium patients.
+ Method: Cross-sectional study in older, acutely ill hospitalized patients, comparing biochemical parameters between delirium and non-delirium groups.
+ **Serotonergic Neurotransmission**: Decreased TRP/LNAAs ratio and increased PHE/TYR ratio in delirium patients, suggesting reduced serotonin production and BH4 deficiency.
+ **Oxidative Stress**: Lower arginine and citrulline levels in delirium patients, indicating increased oxidative stress.

column1: * **Global and Dutch Overweight and Obesity Prevalence:**

column2: + Over 1.4 billion adults worldwide were overweight in 2008, with 200 million men and 300 million women considered obese.
+ In the Netherlands, 60% (14% obese) of men and 44% (13% obese) of women were overweight.
+ Increased risk of cancer, cardiovascular diseases, diabetes, and mobility problems.
+ At least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic physical activity per week.
+ Active transport (walking, cycling) can help achieve sufficient levels of physical activity.
+ Age and overweight inversely correlated with physical activity.
+ Male gender and white ethnic origin positively correlated with being active.
+ Studies found positive relations between physical activity and neighborhood walkability.
+ High-income populations tend to live in more walkable neighborhoods and have higher activity levels.
+ Higher prevalence of overweight and lower levels of physical activity compared to the average Dutch population.
+ Important target group for physical activity interventions.
+ Longitudinal study evaluating health impact of area-based interventions in 40 most severely deprived neighborhoods in the Netherlands.
+ 622 participants from 20 deprived neighborhoods.
+ Minutes per week spent on walking or cycling for active transport.
+ Neighborhood Walkability Scale (NEWS) assessed neighborhood environmental characteristics.
+ Age, neighborhood status, and perceived speed of traffic significantly associated with walking.
+ Age, ethnicity, and neighborhood surroundings significantly associated with cycling.
+ Interactions between ethnicity, sex, age, and perceived traffic safety significantly associated with active transport.
+ Cross-sectional data, low response rate, self-reported measures, and abbreviated NEWS questionnaire.
+ Further research needed to test causality and develop effective interventions for subgroups most in need.
+ *Occurrence:*

column3: - Acute optic neuropathy in young people, especially women
- Unilateral, more frequent in women (70%)
- Incidence: 1-5 per 100,000 annually

column2: + *Symptoms:*

column3: - Decline in visual acuity
- Eye pain increasing with eye movements
- Decline in contrast sensitivity
- Dyschromatopsia and visual field changes

column2: + *Study Aims:*

column3: - Determine optic neuritis as the first MS clinical presentation
- Analyze morphometric changes in optic nerve and visual field using OCT and computer perimetry
- Evaluate the efficiency of pulse corticosteroid therapy

column2: + *Patient Demographics:*

column3: - Most patients aged 18-30 years
- Female predominance (70%)

column2: + *Ophthalmological Parameters:*

column3: - Centrocecal scotoma most frequent (50%)
- RNFL thinning, especially in the upper quadrant (after 3 months)
- Visual acuity improvement after corticosteroid therapy (0.6-1.0 after 1 month)

column2: + *MS Diagnosis and Progression:*

column3: - Optic neuritis as the first clinical sign of MS (statistically significant)
- 50% of ON patients develop MS over 15 years
- 75% of ON patients with MRI changes develop MS

column2: + *Treatment and Prognosis:*

column3: - Pulse corticosteroid therapy effective in improving visual acuity
- Corticosteroids prevent ON relapse but have limited long-term effect on MS development
- OCT confirms nerve fiber atrophy after ON

column1: * **Diabetes Knowledge Assessment among Karen Ethnic Rural Community**

column2: + **Low Overall Knowledge**

column3: - One-third answered correctly, another third gave no answer, and another third gave wrong answers.
- Less than 30% knew about fasting blood glucose level and symptoms, diagnosis, and complications of diabetes.

column2: + **Gender Disparity in Knowledge**

column3: - Female participants had lower knowledge levels than male participants.
- Median sum of knowledge scores was 6 for males and 3 for females.

column2: + **Risk Factor and Symptom Awareness**

column3: - Only one-third knew about diabetes risk factors.
- Knowledge of diabetes symptoms was also low, with a skewed distribution towards lower scores.

column1: • **Behavioral Health Home (BHH) for individuals with Serious Mental Illness (SMI)**

column2: • • **Purpose**: To improve somatic care and identify gaps in care for individuals with SMI.
• • **Setting**: Embedded in the Division of Community Psychiatry at the University of Maryland School of Medicine.
• • **Services**: Care coordination, transitional care, health promotion, and population-based health management for highly prevalent somatic conditions like diabetes and hypertension.
• • **Enrollment**: 120 patients with SMI enrolled within 10 months.
• • • Average age: 50 years (SD = 12.75 years).
• • • 45% (54 patients) did not have HbA1c levels checked as per clinic guidelines.
• • **Diabetes and Prediabetes**: 33 patients with type 2 diabetes (4 newly diagnosed), 39 patients with prediabetes.

• • • 12% (4 patients) improved to recommended HbA1c levels, 21% (7 patients) showed improvements but remained above target, 6% (2 patients) moved from prediabetes to diabetes, and 12% (7 patients) had higher HbA1c levels.
• • **Potential Benefits**: Identifies gaps in care, promotes preventative care, and may decrease mortality and morbidity rates.
• • • A CDC diabetes prevention program group started within the mental health clinic.
• • **Limitations and Future Research**: Not all patients received equal amounts of services, lack of comparison group, need for patient satisfaction examination, and further empirical data.
+ • Neo-Malthusian Male Breadwinner Hypothesis

column3: - Men's income and employment status influence marriage timing
- Men's economic resources are crucial for setting up a household

column2: + • Career Uncertainty Hypothesis

column3: - Men's employment instability and lack of work experience deter marriage
- Men's economic uncertainty affects their desirability as partners

column2: + • Employment and Income Effects on Union Formation

column3: - Men's employment and income positively influence union formation
- Temporary employment and low income negatively impact union formation

column2: + • Effects on Marriage vs. Cohabitation

column3: - Employment uncertainty reduces the likelihood of marriage
- Income effects are weaker for cohabitation than marriage

column2: + • Effects on Transition from Cohabitation to Marriage

column3: - Employment and income effects are weaker for this transition
- Other factors, such as buying a house or having a child, may influence the decision to marry

column2: + • Traditional vs. Egalitarian Societies

column3: - Men's economic position is more influential in traditional societies
- Income effects are weaker in egalitarian societies

column2: + • Importance of Women's Economic Status

column3: - Women's economic stability and career prospects may also influence marriage timing
- Simultaneous examination of men and women's economic status is crucial for understanding trends and differentials in marriage and cohabitation

column2: + *Causes of Bone Loss in MS*

column3: - *Reduced Mechanical Stress*
- *Glucocorticoid (GC) Treatment*

column4: + Bone loss and increased fracture risk
+ Complex mechanism involving vitamin D insufficiency and physical disability
+ High-dose, short-term intravenous GC regimens decrease bone formation and increase bone resorption

column3: - *Vitamin D Deficiency*

column4: + Contributes to bone remodeling imbalance and bone loss
+ GC treatment increases risk for vitamin D insufficiency/deficiency

column2: + *Risk Factors for Osteoporosis in MS*

column3: - *Level of Disability (Motor Disability)*

column4: + Edss score of 6 or greater indicates need for BMD measurement

column3: - *Long-term GC Treatment*

column4: + Increases risk of bone loss and fractures
+ BMD measurement recommended for patients on 5 mg prednisone equivalents daily for more than 3 months

column3: - *Vitamin D Deficiency*

column4: + Contributes to bone loss and increased fracture risk
+ BMD measurement recommended for patients with vitamin D deficiency

column2: + *Diagnosis and Management of Osteoporosis in MS*

column3: - *Clinical Evaluation*

column4: + Assessment of clinical risk factors for osteoporosis and fractures
+ Examination of motor function using Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) score

column3: - *Bone Mineral Density (BMD) Testing*

column4: + Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) at lumbar spine and hip
+ Recommended for patients with EDSS score of 6 or greater, long-term GC treatment, or vitamin D deficiency

column3: - *Pharmacological Therapy*

column4: + Antiresorptive drugs (e.g., bisphosphonates) or anabolic agents (e.g., teriparatide)
+ Consideration of underlying pathogenesis and individual patient factors
+ Early identification and preventive treatment to avoid bone loss and fractures

column1: • Half a million people affected annually
• Five species affecting humans: P. falciparum, P. vivax, P. malariae, P. ovale, and P. knowlesi
• Prevalent species in tropical areas: P. falciparum, P. vivax, and P. malariae
• Treatment for P. vivax malaria: Chloroquine (30 mg/kg over 3 days) and Primaquine (0.25 mg/kg/day for 7-14 days)
• Primaquine: Hemolytic effects (especially in G6PD deficiency), gastrointestinal disorders, and skin reactions
• Chloroquine: Retinopathy, cardiomyopathy, myopathy, neuromyopathy, gastrointestinal tract adverse reactions, ototoxicity, and skin changes
* **Global Trends in Longevity and Aging Population**

column2: + Increased lifespan and aging population worldwide
+ Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS), erectile dysfunction (ED), and decreased libido in elderly men
+ Strong correlation between sexual dysfunction, aging, and LUTS severity
+ Increased prevalence of LUTS and ED with age
+ Synchronous presence of LUTS and ED in many cases

column1: * **Hypothesized Pathophysiology of LUTS and ED Correlation**

column2: + Overactivation of autonomic nervous system and increased sympathetic tension
+ Endothelial dysfunction and hormonal imbalance
+ Lifestyle changes due to nocturia and rapid eye movement sleep disorder
+ Examine effects of tamsulosin (alpha-blocker) and solifenacin (antimuscarinic agent) combination on erectile function in men with LUTS/BPH and ED
+ Randomized controlled trial with 60 male patients aged 40 or older
+ Significant improvement in LUTS symptoms (total, voiding, storage, and quality of life) after 3-month treatment in both groups
+ No significant differences in sexual function (iIEF-5) improvement between groups
+ Significant association between improved storage symptoms (iPSS-st) and improved sexual function (iIEF-5) in the tamsulosin-only group, but not in the combination group
+ Concomitant use of alpha-blockers and antimuscarinics may improve LUTS but not sexual function in men with LUTS/BPH and ED
+ Further studies are needed to investigate the effects of antimuscarinic agents on sexual function in LUTS/BPH patients
+ Mir-200c is expressed in an epithelial cell-specific manner and can act as a tumor suppressor.
+ It can repress the expression of zeb1 and zeb2, which are involved in the epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) process.
+ Mir-200c can also repress a program of transcripts normally expressed in cells of mesenchymal origin.
+ Mir-200c and zeb1 regulate each other in a double-negative feedback loop.
+ TGF-β plays a central role in this feedback loop during EMT.

column1: * **Effects of mir-200c restoration in cancer cells:**

column2: + Mir-200c restoration can decrease cell migration, invasion, and adhesion to substrates.
+ It can also increase chemosensitivity to microtubule-targeting agents like paclitaxel.

column1: * **Mir-200c and zeb1 relationship in different cell lines:**

column2: + The double-negative feedback loop between mir-200c and zeb1 is not functional in all cell lines.
+ In some cell lines, the decrease in proliferation is due to the lack of zeb1, not an increase in mir-200c.
+ The decrease in adhesion to substrates is a function of mir-200c expression rather than zeb1.
+ Mir-200c can directly target and repress tubulin (TUBB3), which is associated with resistance to taxanes.
+ Downregulation of tubulin, not increased proliferation, is responsible for the enhanced chemosensitivity to taxanes observed with mir-200c restoration.
+ Compare the relationship between midurethral sling (MUS) and urethra in inside-out (In-Out) and outside-in (Out-In) transobturator approaches.
+ Cadaveric study using CT-scan image analysis with tantalum wire-marked mesh slings.
+ Both approaches performed on each cadaver, alternating sides and tape types.
+ In-Out approach angulated more acutely around the urethra (122°) than Out-In (144°).
+ Tapes lie posterior/dorsal to the urethra, not inferior.
+ Out-In tapes wrapped more closely around the inferior ischio-pubic ramus.
+ Surgeons should pay attention to the second half of the helical pass for both approaches.
+ In-Out: Rotate hard and carefully around the ischiopubic ramus.
+ Out-In: Ensure full thickness vaginal epithelial layer in peri-urethral tunnel dissection.
+ Static anatomic findings, no clinical correlation.
+ No measurement of distances to obturator nerve branches.
+ Three-dimensional ultrasonography for in vivo dynamic measurements.
+ New MRI-compatible mesh for better understanding of mesh-tissue interaction.
