column1: • **Post-legislative Scrutiny of the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015**

column2: + Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Huw Morris, Director of the Skills, Higher Education and Lifelong Learning Group, attended the committee meeting.
+ The Minister stated that the 2015 Act will be superceded by the new PCETR Bill.
+ The Minister acknowledged that the Act has fulfilled some government objectives but has weaknesses and missed opportunities.
+ The Minister agreed that the Act did not encourage collaboration for widening access activity.
+ The Minister expressed concerns about the lack of confidence in fee and access plans and the need for better outcomes and outputs.
+ The Minister stated that the new Bill will introduce outcome agreements and a regulatory condition for good governance.
+ The Minister confirmed that the new Bill will not introduce a single quality assurance body or framework.
+ The Minister reassured vice-chancellors that the new Bill will not risk the reputation of Welsh universities in transnational education.
+ The Minister thanked the committee for their questions and attendance.

column1: • **Post-legislative Scrutiny of the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015**

column2: + Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Huw Morris, Director of the Skills, Higher Education and Lifelong Learning Group, attended the meeting.
+ The Minister stated that the 2015 Act will be superceded by the new PCETR Bill.
+ The Minister agreed that the Act has fulfilled some but not all of the Government's objectives.
+ The Minister acknowledged that the Act has not been strong enough, and some objectives have been driven through the annual remit letter.
+ The Minister confirmed that the new Bill will continue with the requirement for regulated institutions to be charities.
+ The Minister stated that the new Bill will introduce outcome agreements, replacing fee and access plans.
+ The Minister agreed that the new Bill will address issues around governance and quality assurance.

column1: • **Post-legislative Scrutiny of the Higher Education (Wales) Act 2015**

column2: + Kirsty Williams AM, Minister for Education, and Huw Morris, Director of the Skills, Higher Education and Lifelong Learning Group, attended the meeting.
+ The Minister stated that the 2015 Act will be superceded by the new PCETR Bill.
+ The Minister acknowledged that the Act has fulfilled some Government objectives but has weaknesses.
+ The Minister agreed that the Act has not encouraged collaboration for widening access activity.
+ The Minister expressed concern about the lack of confidence in fee and access plans.
+ The Minister stated that the new Bill will introduce outcome agreements and strengthen regulation of private providers.
+ The Minister agreed that the new Bill will address governance issues and potentially introduce a single quality assurance body.
+ The Minister reassured vice-chancellors that quality assurance changes will not risk the sector's reputation.
+ The Minister acknowledged the potential risks of transnational education and the need for appropriate regulation.
+ The Minister thanked the committee for their questions and attendance.

column2: + Discuss database format for word transcripts and annotations
+ Consider using NIST's ATLAS format
+ Evaluate P-file format for frame-level representation
+ Grad C has developed an XML format for this purpose
+ NIST has developed ATLAS format
+ Both formats have pros and cons
+ Developed by NIST for their evaluation campaign
+ Uses a graph representation with nodes and links
+ Can represent hierarchical relationships between annotations
+ Has an API that is independent of the back-end storage
+ Grad C suggests looking into it further
+ Developed at ICSI for frame-level representation
+ Has an API and libraries for handling P-files
+ Grad C is familiar with it and suggests considering it
+ May not be suitable for very large files due to filesystem limits
+ Contains utilities for handling P-files
+ Has a bunch of things to handle P-files
+ Grad C mentions it as an option
+ Will be automatically generated and not hand-annotated
+ Will be at word-level or segment-level
+ Will not be at phone-level or frame-level
+ Postdoc E suggests tying overlap codes to the first word in the overlap
+ This would provide a unique time-mark independent of time bins
+ Would be useful for merging different annotations
+ PhD A mentions the difficulty of merging different annotations
+ Suggests a tool to merge annotations back into a single version
+ No file format can help with this
+ Grad C will look into the ATLAS format again
+ Consider using the P-file format for frame-level representation
+ Evaluate the pros and cons of each format
+ Consider the learning curve and community ties for each format

column1: 851,"The meeting discussed the design and features of a new remote control for televisions. The project manager presented the minutes of the last meeting and outlined the agenda for the current meeting. The marketing director presented his findings on the functional requirements for the remote control, based on a survey of users. The industrial designer presented his ideas for the design and functionality of the remote control, focusing on the user interface and the technical aspects of the design. The project manager then presented his ideas for the design and functionality of the remote control, focusing on the user interface and the technical aspects of the design. The group then discussed the possibility of including an L_C_D_ screen and speech recognition in the remote control, and decided to do further research on the feasibility and cost of these features. The group also discussed the possibility of including a rechargeable battery in the remote control, and decided to include this feature if possible. The group then discussed the possibility of including a beep or flash feature in the remote control to help users locate it when it is lost, and decided to include this feature if possible. The group then discussed the possibility of including a docking station in the remote control to charge the battery and display information, and decided to include this feature if possible. The group then discussed the possibility of including a cover for the remote control to change its appearance, and decided to include this feature if possible. The group then discussed the possibility of including a menu button in the remote control to access additional functions, and decided to include this feature if possible. The group then discussed the possibility of including a mute button in the remote control, and decided to include this feature if possible. The group then discussed the possibility of including a power button in the remote control, and decided to include this feature if possible. The group then discussed the possibility of including a channel up/down button in the remote control, and decided to include this feature if possible. The group then discussed the possibility of including a volume up/down button in the remote control, and decided to include this feature if possible. The group then discussed the possibility of including a menu button in the remote control, and decided to include this feature if possible. The group then discussed the possibility of including a mute button in the remote control, and decided to include this feature if possible. • **Dr Frank Atherton's views on obesity and overweight in Wales:**

column2: + • High prevalence of overweight and obesity among adults and children.
+ • Consequences of obesity for children include increased risk of overweight adults, diabetes, cancer, and other diseases.
+ • Need to focus on children and future generations to prevent obesity.
+ • Importance of engaging with children and young people in the consultation process.
+ • Not ruling out the possibility of a target.
+ • Need to consider deliverability and challenge when choosing a target.
+ • Importance of evaluation and metrics to measure progress.
+ • Need for additional resource to implement the plan.
+ • PS8 million to PS10 million per year bandied around as a possible figure.
+ • Importance of making best use of existing resources and programmes.
+ • Sugary soft drinks levy revenue could be used to support efforts.
+ • Possibility of using the planning system to restrict hot food takeaways around schools.
+ • Need for further discussion and consultation on this issue.
+ • Importance of creating healthy settings and environments.
+ • Need for changing rooms and toilet facilities in new schools to support community activity.
+ • Importance of making schools accessible to the wider public.
+ • Importance of embedding physical activity at an early stage in primary school education.
+ • Need for statutory guidance on physical education.
+ • Importance of making physical activity enjoyable and attractive to children.
+ • Potential benefits of extending free school meals to all pupils.
+ • Importance of quality of food and access to food for hungry children.
+ • Time frame for review: early autumn 2019.
+ • Essential elements of a clinical obesity pathway: tiered approach, identification of overweight children, targeted support for very overweight children.
+ • Importance of addressing inequalities in overweight and obesity.
+ • Need for bolder action to support low-income families in eating healthily.
+ • Importance of making every contact count in the",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"

column1: • **Dr Frank Atherton's views on targets and investment:**

column2: + Dr Frank Atherton is open to the idea of having a target to reduce childhood obesity in Wales.
+ He believes that the target should be challenging yet deliverable.
+ He thinks that the Welsh Government should consider using the revenue from the soft drinks levy to support obesity prevention initiatives.

column1: • **Dr Frank Atherton's views on the planning system and hot food takeaways:**

column2: + Dr Frank Atherton supports the idea of using the planning system to restrict hot food takeaways near schools.
+ He believes that local authorities could use their powers to implement such restrictions.
+ He mentioned that some local authorities have already put moratoriums on new fast-food venues near schools.

column1: • **Dr Frank Atherton's views on community sport infrastructure and new schools:**

column2: + Dr Frank Atherton thinks that new schools should be built with changing rooms and toilet facilities to accommodate community use.
+ He believes that health impact assessments should be used to inform the design and building of public infrastructure.
+ He mentioned that some schools are already using their sports facilities for community activities.

column2: • Presentation by Industrial Designer
• Looks important for new remote
• Nine channel buttons, volume buttons, etc.
• Speech recognition feature
• Child-friendly design with few buttons
• Oversized remote to prevent loss
• Will it sell?
• Show prototype to various groups
• Consumer research groups
• Intuition and best features to sell
• Biomorphic shape, small size, bright colours
• Soft buttons and comfortable feel
• Functionality: good job, room for improvement
• Happy with creativity and new product
• Good teamwork and leadership
• Happy with means used (whiteboard, slides)
• Found new ideas
• Costs within budget, project evaluated
• Apple juice today, champagne later
• Voice recognition feature to be added
• More buttons for speech recording
• Consolidate volume control
• Leave space for voice recogniser in budget
• Looks were considered very important for the new remote
• It should have nine channel buttons, volume buttons, subtitle buttons, switch to control features, color contrast, sharpness, etc.
• Speech recognition was a favorite feature of the project manager
• The remote should be child-friendly with few buttons and colorful design
• The prototype was presented in the shape of a snail
• It had a blue color with yellow buttons and was compact and easy to hold
• The material used was plastic for the case and soft rubber for the buttons
• It had a fluorescent green LED and an oversized case to prevent loss
• The marketing expert liked the one-thumb operation and the prominent on-off button
• She suggested using fruit and vegetable design and a soft feel for the remote
• She thought the speech recognition feature was the main selling point
• She suggested using the snail's slow nature as a marketing gimmick
• The project was well within budget, with a total cost of €8.20
• The marketing expert gave the prototype a score of 5 out of 7 for functionality
• The team was happy with the project process, leadership, and teamwork
• They felt they had found new ideas and that the project was feasible from both production and marketing perspectives

column1: 920,"The project manager led a discussion about the kinetic function of the remote control. The team decided to remove it due to its high cost and lack of innovation. They also discussed the design of the remote control, with the industrial designer presenting a prototype with a single touch-screen and curved shape. The marketing expert evaluated the prototype based on user requirements and trends analysis, using a seven-point scale. The team then evaluated the design's functionality and aesthetics, and discussed the production costs. They decided to make the remote control with a curved shape, but without the kinetic function. The project manager then asked the team about their experience with the project, and they discussed the leadership, teamwork, and new ideas for the software. The project manager then asked about the end report, and the team agreed to read it and provide feedback.",0,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"

921,"The meeting discussed the design and functionality of a new remote control. The remote control will have a touch screen and will be designed for people under 40 years old. The team decided to use a single touch screen and placed the buttons on top for easy thumb access. The menu structure was also discussed, with the main buttons being changeable by the user. The team also decided to include speech recognition and built-in games in the remote control. The evaluation criteria for the remote control were also discussed, with the team agreeing that the remote control should be innovative, multifunctional, and easy to use. The team also discussed the production costs of the remote control, with the goal of keeping it under 12.50 Euros. The team decided to use a kinetic energy harvester as a marketing promotion, but this would increase the cost to 13.50 Euros. The team also discussed the possibility of using a digital pen for drawing on the touch screen, but this was not found to be user-friendly. The team also discussed the possibility of using a voting application for group decisions, but this was also not found to be ideal. The team ended the meeting by celebrating the successful completion of the project.

column2: + Introduced to remove reasonable punishment defence for common assault
+ Aimed at protecting children's rights and ensuring consistency with other legislation
+ Over 70% of respondents to written consultation did not support the Bill
+ Parents who met with the committee opposed the Bill
+ Established to address practical implications of the Bill
+ Includes representatives from police, social services, education, and other relevant organizations
+ Essential for the Bill to be effective
+ Will be big and comprehensive, involving all relevant agencies
+ Balancing relevant articles of the European Convention on Human Rights
+ Considering articles 3, 8, 9, and 14
+ 58% of the public think the law does not allow parents to smack their children
+ Awareness campaign needed to clarify the law
+ No signs of polarisation in Wales
+ Importance of consensual approach and respect for democratic process
+ Overwhelming majority of parents do not support the Bill
+ Support lies more with parents of young children and younger people
+ Linked to past experiences and societal norms
+ Times have changed, and children's rights should be respected

+ *Purpose*: Conceptual design meeting for a new remote control.
+ *Attendees*: Project Manager, Industrial Designer, Marketing, User Interface (UI) Designer.
+ *Agenda*: Opening the meeting, reviewing previous meeting minutes, presentations, decisions, and closing the meeting.
+ *Project Manager*: Summarized the previous meeting and outlined the agenda.
+ *Industrial Designer*:

column3: - Presented on energy sources (battery, kinetic, solar).
- Discussed case materials (plastic, rubber, titanium, wood).
- Explained interface types (push button, scroll buttons, L_C_D_ display).
- Mentioned new components (sample sensor, sample speaker).

column2: + *Marketing*:

column3: - Presented on marketing research (trends, priorities).
- Suggested a fruit-themed design with interchangeable sleeves.
- Proposed naming the product ""Blackberry"".

column2: + *UI Designer*:

column3: - Presented on interface design (iPod-style scroll wheel, chunky plastic remote).
- Suggested a simple, cost-effective design with a screen on the TV.
- Proposed using plastic or rubber for the case.

column2: + *Kate (UI Designer)*:

column3: - Presented on interface design (scroll wheel, chunky plastic remote).
- Suggested a simple, cost-effective design with a screen on the TV.
- Proposed using plastic or rubber for the case.

column2: + *Energy Source*: Chose kinetic energy source for environmental friendliness and cost savings.
+ *Case Material*: Chose rubber for a spongy feel and plastic inner shell for protection.
+ *Interface Type*: Chose push buttons with up, down, left, right, and enter for simplicity and cost-effectiveness.
+ *Project Manager*: Scheduled the next meeting for thirty minutes later.
+ *Industrial Designer* & *UI Designer*: Assigned to create a prototype using Play-Doh.
+ *Marketing*: Assigned to product evaluation.
+ *Battery*

column2: + Minister Williams stated that schools will move to a new phase when it is safe to do so.
+ She has not given a date for reopening and does not expect it to be imminent.
+ The decision will be based on advice from the chief medical officer and chief scientific officer.
+ Around 600 vulnerable children are currently attending school hubs.
+ The number has doubled since the start of the summer term.
+ The Minister is working with local authorities to encourage more vulnerable children to attend hubs.
+ Testing is crucial for the next phase of relaxing restrictions.
+ The Minister is working with Public Health Wales to ensure that teachers and staff are tested if they exhibit symptoms.
+ As of now, 15 teachers have been tested, with 2 positive results.

column1: • **Kirsty Williams AM's Statement on Schools Reopening**

column2: + • **Five Principles for Reopening Schools**

column3: - • Safety and well-being of children, young people, and staff
- • Decision in context of wider Welsh Government response to pandemic
- • Clear communication to parents and staff
- • Identification of priority groups of children
- • Operationalization of safe school settings

column2: + • **No Imminent Return to Normal**

column3: - • Not feasible to move from current phase to normal education
- • No date given for reopening schools

column2: + • **Support for Vulnerable Children**

column3: - • 5.6% of teaching population working in hubs
- • 85% of children attending are key workers' children
- • Local authorities working to identify and support vulnerable children

column2: + • **Testing and Tracing**

column3: - • Crucial for next phase of Government's response to pandemic
- • Importance of testing for reopening schools

column2: + • **Impact on Children's Mental Health**

column3: - • Additional £1.25 million for school counselling
- • Support for children and families through remote contact

column2: + • **Examinations**

column3: - • GCSE and A-level results day to run as normal
- • Qualifications Wales to allocate grades based on teacher assessment and moderation

column1: • **Meeting with Welsh Government on Impact of Coronavirus on Education**

column2: + • **Purpose of the Meeting**

column3: - To discuss the impact of the coronavirus epidemic on education in Wales.
- To hear from the Minister for Education about the Welsh Government's response to the pandemic.

column2: + • **Attendance**

column3: - Lynne Neagle AM (Chair)
- Kirsty Williams AM (Minister for Education)
- Steve Davies (Director of Education)
- Huw Morris (Group Director, Skills, Higher Education and Lifelong Learning)

column2: + • **Opening Statement by Minister**

column3: - Gratitude to school staff, key workers, and parents for their efforts during the pandemic.
- Primary concern is the health and well-being of children, young people, and staff.
- Education system is facing many challenges due to the pandemic.

column2: + • **Five Principles for Reopening Schools**

column3: - Safety and physical and emotional well-being of children and staff.
- Decision-making in the context of the wider Welsh Government response to the pandemic.
- Clear communication with parents and staff about the basis of decisions.
- Identification of priority groups of children to return to school first.
- Operationalising safety measures in schools.

column2: + • **Questions from Committee Members**

column3: - **Hefin David AM**

column4: + • What is the impact on vulnerable children and additional learning needs pupils?

column3: - **Sian Gwenllian AM**

column4: + • What is the current situation for vulnerable children and key workers' children in school hubs?
+ • How many school staff have been tested for COVID-19?

column3: - **Dawn Bowden AM**

column4: + • What is being done to facilitate more vulnerable children attending school hubs?
+ • How will the attainment gap between disadvantaged pupils and their more affluent peers be addressed?

column3: - **Suzy Davies AM**

column4: + • What is the Welsh Government doing to support vocational learners and their assessments?
+ • How will A-level and GCSE qualifications be awarded this summer?
+ • What is happening with unconditional offers for university entry?
+ • What is the Welsh Government doing to support students with maintenance loan grants?

column2: + • **Conclusion**

column3: - The meeting discussed the impact of the coronavirus epidemic",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"

column1: * **Impact of COVID-19 on Education in Wales**

column2: + **School Hubs**

column3: - 518 hubs open each day
- 4,200 children attending
- 5.6% of teaching population working
- 85% of children are key workers' children
- 15% are vulnerable children

column2: + **Vulnerable Children**

column3: - 600 vulnerable children per day
- Numbers have doubled since Easter
- Risk assessments for vulnerable children
- Support for children with additional learning needs

column2: + **Testing**

column3: - 15 teachers tested for COVID-19
- 2 positive results
- Guidance for teachers and staff

column2: + **School Attendance**

column3: - Relaxation of truancy rules
- Suspension of performance measures
- No literacy and numeracy testing

column2: + **Examinations**

column3: - GCSE and A-level exams cancelled
- Teachers to submit grades for students
- Moderation process to follow
- A-level results day to run as normal

column2: + **Higher Education**

column3: - Virtual learning resources available
- Unconditional offers moratorium in place
- Student support payments unaffected
- Conversations with NUS Wales and HEFCW

column2: + **Four-Nation Approach**

column3: - Collaboration with Northern Ireland, Scotland, and England
- Sharing of best practices and resources
- Coordination of responses to COVID-19

column2: + As of yesterday, 518 school hubs are open each day, with up to 4,200 children attending.
+ Around 5.6% of the teaching population is working in these hubs, with 85% of the children being key workers' children and the remaining 15% being vulnerable children.
+ There are around 600 vulnerable children attending hubs daily.
+ Children with additional learning needs are being supported through risk assessments and conversations with families.
+ Around 518 school hubs open each day, with up to 4,200 children attending.
+ Around 5.6% of the teaching population working in hubs.
+ Around 85% of children attending are key workers' children, with the rest being vulnerable children.
+ Around 600 vulnerable children per day attending hubs.
+ Numbers have doubled since the start of the traditional summer term.
+ Local authorities are working to identify and support vulnerable children not currently attending hubs.
+ Schools are operating safely, with local authorities reporting any incidents.
+ Around 15 teachers have been tested for COVID-19, with 2 positive results.
+ Testing, tracing, and quarantine will be crucial for schools to reopen safely.

column1: • 518 school hubs open each day, with up to 4,200 children attending.
• 5.6% of the teaching population working in hubs.
• 85% of children attending are key workers' children, with the remainder being vulnerable children.
• Numbers have doubled since the start of the traditional summer term.
• Local authorities are working to identify and support vulnerable children not currently attending hubs.
• Schools are conducting regular telephone check-ins with families and children.
• Schools are risk assessing ALN children to determine if they should attend hubs.
• Local authorities are supporting families and providing specialist support where appropriate.
• Support available via telephone and video calls, as well as remote counselling and therapy.
• Concerns about the attainment gap between disadvantaged pupils and their more affluent peers.
• Digital disadvantage and lack of access to technology are potential barriers to learning.

column3: - Compromised ability to deliver business as usual
- Uncertainty about continuation of process

column2: + • **Emergency Response (Monday)**

column3: - Schools closed for most pupils
- Headteachers and staff expected to be in school
- Planning for vulnerable children and key workers' children

column2: + • **Long-term Provision**

column3: - Strategic pattern of schools to operate
- Staffing and resources to be considered by local authorities
- Youth workers, sports development officers, and cultural officers to be deployed

column2: + • **Cancellation of Exams**

column3: - All exams cancelled for GCSE, AS, A-level, and vocational qualifications
- Learners to be awarded fair grades based on available information

column3: - Modulated arrangement across the UK to maintain standards
- Teacher evaluation of students to be considered

column1: * **Impact of Coronavirus Pandemic on Education in Wales**

column2: + **School Closures and New Purpose**

column3: - *Schools closed from March 20 for statutory education provision*
- *New purpose: support vulnerable children, children of key workers, and free school meal provision*
- *Schools to remain open for staff to plan and deliver services*
- *Local authorities and schools to work together to identify vulnerable children*

column2: + **Exam Cancellations and Alternatives**

column3: - *Summer exam series cancelled*
- *Learners to be awarded fair grades based on available evidence*
- *Qualifications Wales and WJEC to communicate with schools about grading process*
- *Universities and UCAS to accept students based on awarded grades*

column2: + **Vulnerable Learners and Additional Support**

column3: - *Schools to provide safe and secure places for children of key workers*
- *Free school meals to be provided during school closures*
- *Additional learning needs pupils to be supported*
- *Youth services to play an important role in supporting vulnerable children*

column2: + **Emergency Legislation**

column3: - *Emergency legislation to provide Welsh Ministers with powers to temporarily close or open educational institutions*
- *Powers to direct resources and relax requirements around ratios in childcare settings*
- *Powers to suspend or direct things as needed*
- *Insurance claims may not be covered even with Government directions*

column2: + • Schools closed from March 20 for statutory education provision.
+ • New purpose: support key workers'children, vulnerable children, and those with additional learning needs.
+ • Schools to provide safe and secure places for children of key workers.
+ • Free school meals to be provided.
+ • Additional learning needs to be addressed.
+ • Schools to plan for delivery post Easter.
+ • Schools to be open for staff to plan and prepare.
+ • Summer exam series cancelled.
+ • Learners to be awarded fair grades based on available information.
+ • Qualifications Wales and WJEC to communicate with schools about awarding grades.
+ • Universities to accept students based on awarded grades.
+ • BTECs and other vocational qualifications to be awarded based on modular, continually-assessed work.
+ • ATT qualification status unknown.",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"

column1: * **Impact of Coronavirus Pandemic on Education in Wales**

column2: + **School Closures and New Purpose**

column3: - Schools closed from March 20 for statutory education provision
- New purpose: support key workers' children, vulnerable children, and those with additional learning needs
- Schools to provide safe and secure places for children of key workers
- Free school meals, additional learning needs, and safeguarding to be prioritized

column2: + **Exams and Assessment**

column3: - Summer exam series cancelled
- Learners to be awarded fair grade based on available information
- Qualifications Wales and WJEC to communicate with schools about assessment process
- Universities and UCAS to accept students based on awarded grades

column2: + **Powers under Emergency Legislation**

column3: - Welsh Ministers to temporarily close or direct educational institutions and resources
- Relax requirements around ratios in childcare settings and food provisions
- Suspend or direct services as needed for resilience

column2: + **Insurance Claims**

column3: - Government directions may not guarantee insurance coverage
- Insurance industry not paying out due to disruption not being covered
- Example: School trips abroad cancellation direction from FCO not covering insurance
- Insurance not Minister's area of expertise

column2: + • The Bill aims to remove the defence of reasonable punishment in Wales.
+ • The current law allows parents to use physical punishment as long as it is reasonable.
+ • The Bill seeks to align Welsh law with the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child.
+ • The Rights of Children and Young Persons (Wales) Measure 2011 already makes provisions for the UNCRC.
+ • Physical punishment is harmful to children.
+ • It can lead to adverse childhood experiences and long-term negative effects.
+ • It is not an effective form of discipline.
+ • It can lead to more serious physical or sexual abuse.
+ • The Bill will bring clarity and remove ambiguity.
+ • It will not lead to a sudden increase in referrals to social services.
+ • It will not criminalise parents who use physical punishment.
+ • It will require awareness raising and training for professionals.
+ • The Bill will have costs associated with it.
+ • These include training, awareness raising, and potential additional resources for social services.
+ • The costs are not yet fully known.
+ • The Welsh Government has committed to fully resourcing the Bill if it is enacted.
+ • There may be unintended consequences of the Bill.
+ • These could include increased referrals to social services or increased awareness of preventative services.
+ • The Bill could also lead to a greater understanding of the UNCRC.
+ • It could reinvigorate discussions about the voice of the child in educational settings.
+ • Awareness raising and training for educational professionals

column3: - Key to supporting implementation of the Bill

column2: + • Clarity for teachers and others working in educational settings

column3: - Important for them to understand their role in supporting the Bill

column2: + • Potential harm to relationships and mistrust

column3: - Referring more parents to social services could cause potential harm
- Trust is key in educational settings

column2: + • Importance of clear communication to parents, guardians, and the public

column3: - Crucial to avoid criminalising parents
- Welsh Government, National Assembly, and local authorities should be involved

column2: + • Awareness raising on the face of the Bill

column3: - Scotland's approach to making it a duty for Ministers to raise awareness
- Welsh Government's commitment to awareness raising
- Clarity and resources for local authorities and front-line services

column2: + • Costs of implementing the Bill

column3: - Unknown costs for different agencies
- Work in progress to identify and quantify costs

column2: + • Funding for social services and preventative services

column3: - Additional investment needed for effective implementation
- Welsh Government's commitment to fully resource the Bill

column2: + • **Referrals and Assessments**

column3: - Social services will continue to assess referrals on a case-by-case basis.
- The number of referrals is expected to peak and then settle.
- The majority of referrals will likely not result in social services intervention.

column2: + • **Thresholds for Intervention**

column3: - The Bill is not expected to change thresholds for social services intervention.
- Social services will continue to prioritize children at risk of significant harm.
- The Bill aims to bring clarity to the existing system, not to create new thresholds.

column2: + • **Unknown Costs**

column3: - The explanatory memorandum accompanying the Bill acknowledges unknown costs for different agencies.
- Sally Jenkins and Huw David emphasize the need to identify and quantify these costs.
- Sian Gwenllian suggests that forecasting costs could help calm fears and make a case for or against the Bill.

column2: + • **Funding Commitment**

column3: - Huw David argues that the National Assembly for Wales should commit to fully resourcing the Bill, regardless of the costs.
- He emphasizes that the Bill should not come at the expense of current service provision to vulnerable families in Wales.
- The committee will need to consider the funding implications of the Bill.

column2: + • Bring clarity to the law regarding physical punishment
+ • Remove a little-used defence
+ • Reflect societal changes in Wales
+ • Protect children's rights
+ • No significant increase in referrals expected
+ • Proportionate response to incidents
+ • Support services for families
+ • No long-term involvement unless necessary
+ • Crucial for success of the Bill
+ • Welsh Government committed to raising awareness
+ • Various routes for awareness raising
+ • Not criminalising parents
+ • Costs quantifiable but challenging
+ • Work ongoing to identify costs
+ • Commitment to full resourcing needed
+ • Additional investment in preventative services
+ • Strategic leadership group to oversee
+ • Clear understanding of trajectory of costs
+ • Welsh Government to honour commitments
+ • Local authorities to be fully involved
+ • Welcomed by witnesses
+ • Clarity and protection for children
+ • Natural progression of change in Wales
+ • No criminalisation of parents
+ The Bill aims to bring clarity and remove an outdated defence.
+ It is not expected to significantly increase referrals to children's services.
+ The Bill's implementation may have associated costs.
+ The Welsh Government has committed to fully resourcing the Bill if enacted.

+ Ted starts wearing an old shirt he didn't like before, symbolizing his changing tastes.
+ He decides to form second impressions about things he previously disliked.
+ Ted considers dating an old flame, Steph, but Lily suggests Natalie instead.
+ Ted calls Natalie, but she hangs up on him.
+ Ted admits to breaking up with Natalie on her answering machine on her birthday.
+ Lily and Marshall express their disapproval of his past actions.
+ Ted visits Natalie with a sock monkey to apologize and ask her out again.
+ They start dating, and Ted feels he should be in love but isn't.
+ Ted tries to find a way to break up with Natalie without hurting her.
+ He decides to tell her the truth, that she's not the one for him.
+ Ted breaks up with Natalie on her birthday, leading to a heated argument.
+ Natalie, knowing Krav Maga, kicks Ted and leaves him bruised.
+ Ted realizes there's no good way to break up with someone, and sometimes honesty can lead to pain.
+ He learns that sometimes things happen for a reason, as Natalie eventually finds happiness with someone else.

+ *Nikolas and Rebecca*: Nikolas decides to end his relationship with Rebecca due to her resemblance to Emily. Rebecca is hurt but understands his decision.
+ *Sonny and Olivia*: Sonny is upset about Olivia's relationship with Johnny Zacchara, his brother-in-law. Olivia seeks Carly's advice on how to handle the situation.
+ *Michael and Johnny*: Michael meets Johnny Zacchara at a bar and they bond over their shared experiences in the mob world. Johnny offers to help Michael with his physical therapy.
+ *Lucky and Elizabeth*: Elizabeth suspects that Rebecca is cheating on Nikolas with Ethan. She tries to convince Lucky to investigate the matter.

+ *Jason and Claudia*: Jason is determined to prove that Claudia was responsible for Michael's shooting. Claudia, however, is confident that she can protect herself and her unborn child from Jason's accusations.
+ *Patrick and Andrea Floyd*: Andrea Floyd, the mayor's wife, tries to convince Patrick to settle the malpractice suit out of court. Patrick refuses, as he believes in his innocence.
+ *Johnny and Claudia*: Claudia asks Johnny to help her get rid of Jason Morgan, as she believes he is a threat to her and her unborn child. Johnny is reluctant but agrees to help.
+ *Nikolas and Rebecca*: Nikolas plans a special evening for him and Rebecca to try and make up for the hurt he caused her. He asks her to wear a specific outfit for the occasion.

+ *Jax and Carly*: Jax plans a surprise for Carly to help her relax and trust Michael to handle his physical therapy on his own. He bribes her with a romantic evening to stay home while Michael is at his appointment.
